A brain guzzler's cybernetics are disabled for 1 hour if it takes any electricity damage. A brain guzzler with disabled cybernetics is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and can't use reactions.
VGtxQgR50RgNXgLv.name: Cybernetics

Ww1mMdRu5yJSpaYj.description:
Trigger The brain guzzler kills an enemy

Effect The brain guzzler breaks open its victim's skull and eats the brain. The brain guzzler gains knowledge of the victim's memories, and its Intelligence increases by +1. The victim can no longer be raised from the dead by any method that requires an intact corpse and rises as a zombie shambler the next day at dawn.
Ww1mMdRu5yJSpaYj.name: Guzzle

YWzEkwp5ZbNl5zmJ.description: The brain guzzler fires with the ulna bow, which rips the ulna out of its own forearm and fires it at one target within 120 feet. The target must succeed at a @Check[reflex|dc:25] save or take @Damage[(3d8+5)[piercing]] damage. The ulna explodes on impact, dealing @Damage[4d8[piercing]] damage to adjacent creatures (@Check[reflex|dc:25|basic] save). Once the ulna bow has been used once it can't be used again.
YWzEkwp5ZbNl5zmJ.name: Ulna Bow

Enraged Bun the Black.description:
Although the glistening scales and sleek, fin-like wings on these drakes give them an appearance reminiscent of river fish, they are actually distant relatives of the dragons that rule the oceans. While smaller than most drakes, river drakes are more than capable of plaguing river travelers and are equally at home above and below the water's surface. This flexibility allows them to catch a wide variety of prey, from fish and boggards to deer and the occasional ferry passenger.

Ravenous, bestial, and driven by instinct, drakes are draconic monsters who bear a fraction of the terrifying might of the primal dragons they share evolutionary roots with. While they're weaker, slower, and less inclined toward reason than dragons, drakes are nonetheless a menace to creatures and settlements around them. Their propensity for forming raiding parties—small social groups fittingly called "rampages"—makes them all the more dangerous; a single rampage of river drakes can quickly lay waste to a waterside village, and roving rampages of desert drakes are a plague to caravan traders.

Drakes share a number of physical characteristics that unite them as one species despite their wide variety of habitats and abilities. For example, drakes lack forearms, leaving them with their formidable jaws and thickscaled tails to use in close combat. Most drakes would rather avoid this, however, preferring to use their magical breath to wreak havoc in wide swaths from comfortable distances while flying overhead. Finally, all drakes have small reservoirs of their ancestral draconic power that they can tap into to perform incredible feats of speed.

Different species of drakes rarely come into conflict. Part of this is their distinct habitats, but drakes are open to negotiating simple agreements between rampages. This courtesy does not extend to dragonets, which drakes happily take as prey. Solitary tamed drakes are also excluded from such agreements and considered free game if their tamer isn't strong enough to protect them.

Drake Eggs

While drake hides aren't any more valuable than those of similarly sized creatures, drake eggs are prized commodities. They are used as components in powerful spells as well as eaten by various cultures, but the most common use for drake eggs is hatching and rearing drakes to serve as mounts and guardians.

A typical drake lays a clutch of 2d4 eggs every 5 years. Eggs hatch within 3 to 6 weeks, during which time they must be kept in conditions appropriate to their natural environment, perhaps the most difficult aspect of drake husbandry. While it is generally easy for breeders to incubate the eggs of desert or jungle drakes (which require mildly warm temperatures to hatch) or river drakes (which must be submerged in running water), the eggs of flame and frost drakes require extreme temperatures in order to hatch, which can be difficult to replicate safely.

A drake egg is an object with Hardness 3, 5 HP, and no Broken Threshold. The coloration of drake eggs varies only slightly from one species to the next. A creature must succeed at a @Check[nature|dc:20] check, or a relevant DC 20 Lore check, to identify the drake species of a specific egg.

Once a drake hatches, they imprint on the first creature that they see. A creature imprinted on in this way can use Nature to Train and Command that drake. The market price of a drake egg varies depending on the type of drake and the exact legal situation. Because drakes are dangerous and intelligent creatures, many societies do not condone the trade of drake eggs and criminalize those who engage in it.

It takes 2 years for a drake hatchling to grow to full size. A well-trained drake can make a fearsome mount or guardian, but many careless would-be drake trainers are devoured by their charges.

GsSxwd5EPNBqxdWC.description: Bun the Black makes one fangs Strike and two tail Strikes in any order.
GsSxwd5EPNBqxdWC.name: Draconic Frenzy

jbjsVEFvVsslwVHa.description:
Trigger A creature within reach of Bun the Black's tail uses an action to Strike or attempt a skill check

Effect Bun the Black attempts to Strike the triggering creature with their tail. If it hits, the target takes a –2 circumstance penalty to the triggering roll.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.QqC9xymSXSVunDgl]{Effect: Tail Lash}
jbjsVEFvVsslwVHa.name: Tail Lash

qugqAWTLubz9fcj2.description:
Frequency three times per day

Effect Bun the Black Strides or Flies twice.
qugqAWTLubz9fcj2.name: Speed Surge

xheziaVMnj1iAjP5.description:
Bun the Black spits a ball of caustic mucus up to a range of 50 feet that explodes in a @Template[type:burst|distance:10]. Creatures within the burst take @Damage[4d8[acid]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:21|basic|options:area-effect] save). Those that fail this save also take @Damage[1d6[persistent,acid]] damage and take a –5-foot status penalty to their Speed. This Speed reduction ends with the persistent acid damage. Bun the Black can't use Caustic Mucus again for [[/gmr 1d6 #Recharge Caustic Mucus]]{1d6 rounds}.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.TbmkcfpKIs558skY]{Effect: Caustic Mucus}
xheziaVMnj1iAjP5.name: Caustic Mucus

Enraged Bun the Black.name: Enraged Bun the Black

11SMR9i2SDGSrgtn.description:
Trigger Rowan has thrown her @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.ZvIEJCY60fHqzl6r]{Serpent Dagger} at a target

Frequency once per turn

Effect After the attack's result is resolved, Rowan yanks on the cord attached to the weapon's hilt, returning it to her hand. If she throws the weapon to a distance of 20 feet or beyond, this ability becomes 1-action and gains the manipulate trait.
11SMR9i2SDGSrgtn.name: Tether Pull

QC1C7qTJXeZS9gNQ.description:
Requirements Rowan is within 30 feet of one of the circular mirrors in the southern two rooms of the laboratory

Effect Rowan uses her connection to the aiudara fragments to translocate. She Strides once into one of the circular mirrors, teleporting to any other such mirror of her choice. When she does this, she leaves behind a mirrored image of herself until the start of her next turn. This image acts as an ally for all purposes, but has an AC of 0, 1 HP, and cannot take actions.
QC1C7qTJXeZS9gNQ.name: Mirror Step

cmGhYmv28lFbpAeV.description: Rowan's strikes deal 1d6 extra damage to creatures who are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} to her, or who are within reach of at least one of her allies.
cmGhYmv28lFbpAeV.name: Flash Attack

Enraged The Heartwood Rots.description:
Vampires use their servitor pawns for infiltration and reconnaissance.

Vampires are undead creatures that feed on the blood of the living.

NuxXjOzgXl6CzF9b.description:
The vampire can cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.OsOhx3TGIZ7AhD0P]{Dominate} at will as a divine innate spell. Casting it requires staring into the target's eyes, giving the spell the visual trait (@Check[will|dc:22]). The save DC uses the high spell DC of the vampire's level, and a creature that succeeds is temporarily immune to that vampire's Dominate for 24 hours.

Fully destroying the vampire ends the domination, but merely reducing the vampire to 0 HP is insufficient to break the spell.
NuxXjOzgXl6CzF9b.name: Dominate

hn5GBufYeA5C1oOg.description:
Requirement A @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious}, or willing creature is within the vampire's reach.

Effect The vampire sinks its fangs into that creature to drink its blood. This requires an @Check[athletics|defense:fortitude] check against the victim's Fortitude DC if the victim is grabbed and is automatic for any of the other conditions.

The victim is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} and the vampire regains @Damage[10[healing]]{10 HP}, gaining any excess HP as temporary Hit Points. Drinking Blood from a creature that's already drained doesn't restore any HP to the vampire but increases the victim's drained value by 1, killing the victim when it reaches drained 5. A vampire can also consume blood that's been emptied into a vessel for sustenance, but it gains no HP from doing so.

A victim's drained condition decreases by 1 per week. A blood transfusion, which requires a @Check[medicine|dc:20|name:Blood Transfusion] check and sufficient blood or a blood donor, reduces the drain by 1 after 10 minutes.
hn5GBufYeA5C1oOg.name: Drink Blood

kztyfqilO3cN1BeS.description: The vampire's presence brings forth creatures of the night to do the master's bidding. These typically include rat swarms, bat swarms, and wolves but can include other creatures. The vampire can give telepathic orders to these creatures as long as they're within 100 feet, but they can't communicate back.
kztyfqilO3cN1BeS.name: Children of the Night

tfYmL4tSNRyScITd.description: When The Heartwood Rots dies, a burst of primal void energy explodes from her body, restoring @Damage[2d8[healing,void]]{2d8} Hit Points to each undead fungi or plant creature in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:30] and killing all natural plants, though merely causing discomfort to creatures with the plant trait. This area is filled with rotten vegetation, becoming difficult terrain.
tfYmL4tSNRyScITd.name: Rotten Burst

Enraged The Heartwood Rots.name: Enraged The Heartwood Rots
Enraged The Heartwood Rots.npcHp: coffin restoration, fast healing 7, void healing

Experienced Homunculus.description:
A homunculus is a tiny servitor construct created by a crafter to serve as a spy, scout, messenger, or assistant. When a crafter first begins to study the art of creating constructs, they often craft a homunculus first, since the creation process is simple and inexpensive due to a magical shortcut: the use of the creator's own blood. This forges a link between the homunculus and its master, causing the homunculus to gain a spark of the creator's intellect, as well as the same moral values and some of the creator's basic personality traits. Homunculi left to their own devices never stray far from their masters.

In most cases, a homunculus doesn't survive the death of its master for long. Deprived of its creator, a homunculus loses focus and grows increasingly selfdestructive, and some even end up battering themselves to annihilation. Rarely, a homunculus with a slain master survives the trauma with its mind intact, often seeing itself as its deceased creator's child or successor and attempting to further its creator's legacy as best it can. In such cases, and if the homunculus was in close proximity to its master upon that creature's death, a portion of the dead master's soul "infects" the surviving homunculus as they pass on to the afterlife.

This doesn't result in a truly soulbound homunculus, since only a fragment of the soul is left behind, but this is still enough to grant the homunculus a greater personality, free will of its own, and perhaps most importantly, the ability to speak. Over time, a few of these "awakened" homunculi even go so far as to become convinced that they are the reincarnation of their prior masters, although their actual personalities never quite reach the depth and complexity of a truly living creature. They are, at best, caricatures of the master, and at worst, they become awful, bitter-minded parodies of life itself. Still, a free-willed homunculus might pursue studies in its creator's class, becoming a unique creature with the abilities of that class if time and fortune permit.

Homunculi are created from a mixture of clay, ash, mandrake root, spring water, and a pint of the creator's own blood. It is possible for a separate donor to provide the blood, but the process is more difficult.

WLKYWXEiwmc9uCr5.description: A homunculus can't speak, but it is telepathically linked to its creator. It can share information back and forth, including its master's knowledge and everything the homunculus hears. The range of this link is 1,500 feet. The homunculus typically has a similar attitude to its creator and is utterly faithful. If the homunculus is destroyed, the master takes @Damage[2d10[mental]] damage. If the master is slain, the homunculus becomes mindless, claims its current location as its lair, and instinctively attacks anyone who comes near.
WLKYWXEiwmc9uCr5.name: Master Link

WhTbPOtlxlYvCpJ6.description:
A homunculus has one dose of poison in a reservoir in its head. It can refill this poison from its reserves with an Interact action

Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:17]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[1d6[poison]] and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} (1 round).
WhTbPOtlxlYvCpJ6.name: Homunculus Poison

Experienced Homunculus.name: Experienced Homunculus

MSReiMw83Vld9Z2y.description: The bandit makes a Strike with the spiked chain, increasing their reach by 5 feet for that Strike. The bandit can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.Dt6B1slsBy8ipJu9]{Disarm} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.ge56Lu1xXVFYUnLP]{Trip} instead of a Strike.
MSReiMw83Vld9Z2y.name: Lunge

Extremely Haunted Hollows.description: The spirits of innumerable dryads and peaceful wood elementals, ripped from their bodies as they were turned into furniture, writhe and seethe, lashing out at both living and undead alike.
Extremely Haunted Hollows.hazardDisable:
@Check[diplomacy|dc:23] (trained), @Check[nature|dc:23] (trained), or @Check[religion|dc:23] (trained) to set the spirits to rest or @Check[deception|dc:27], @Check[intimidation|dc:27], or @Check[occultism|dc:27] to convince the spirits that their eternal rest is coming soon.

A PC may make a Strike against AC 22 to destroy a single table or chair in the room, this functions as a successful check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.HCl3pzVefiv9ZKQW]{Aid} another PC attempting to disable the haunt; two total successes are required to disable the haunt. If all of the tables and chairs are destroyed, the haunt is temporarily disabled until dawn of the next day.
Extremely Haunted Hollows.hazardRoutine: (two actions) The Haunted Hollows haunt uses table flip or chair toss Strikes at different creatures in the area, favoring those who are trying to disable the haunt first, but otherwise choosing randomly. The table flip Strikes originate with any table in the room, destroying the table in the process. The chair toss Strikes originate with any chair or bar stool in the room, destroying that object in the process. If the haunt is not disabled, these objects reform and return to their original positions at dawn of the next day.
Extremely Haunted Hollows.name: Extremely Haunted Hollows

Feral Krooth.description:
Krooths, sometimes called crocodile eaters, are fast and vicious hunters of bogs and wetlands. While they are known to hunt and eat crocodiles, alligators, and virtually any creature with flesh, their favorite prey are lizardfolk, boggards, and dinosaurs.

Krooths are found alone or in packs. Male krooths are solitary and territorial creatures—fierce, bold, and bloodthirsty. Female krooths, on the other hand, are more likely to shy away from potential predators but swiftly turn violent when their brood is threatened. Because their offspring are so vulnerable, female krooths gather in packs to raise their young, sending smaller groups to hunt for food while the rest of the pack watches the brood. Krooths mate only once every 4 or 5 years, and the mating process is a curiously gruesome spectacle. An entire pack of females will hunt as a group for a lone male krooth, claiming their prize in a frenzy that can last for an entire day and night. After the mating has finished, the females slay their mate and devour his nutrientrich flesh, and his organs in particular. These organs contain a unique chemical compound vital to gestation. Many naturalists will pay handsomely for the fresh remains of a male krooth so they can study the strange properties of the creature's blood and organs. In addition, krooths have poisonous, hollow teeth. When these creatures bite their prey, a tooth breaks off and causes the victim to bleed profusely as their blood pours through the hollow tooth.

Whether male or female, krooths seem to be repelled by goblinoid flesh, especially that of bugbears. This doesn't mean krooths won't kill goblinoids, especially those threatening their young, but they typically do so using only their claws and tails, and they take great care to clean themselves thoroughly after such a killing.

LBCwTLpo7BDaFfpf.name: +4 Status to All Saves vs. Fear

QRArjmTp1QFxOrMG.description:
Requirements The krooth damaged a creature with its jaws on its most recent action this turn

Effect The krooth snaps off one of its teeth in the creature it hit. The creature takes @Damage[2d6[persistent,bleed]] damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1}. Neither can be healed while the tooth remains. Removing the tooth safely requires a successful DC 29 check to [[/act administer-first-aid dc=29]]. Instead of ending bleeding or stabilizing, this removes the tooth and the drained condition, but it doesn't automatically end the bleed damage.
QRArjmTp1QFxOrMG.name: Poison Tooth

qY4Gqits5ZaytjDY.description:
Whenever the krooth is damaged by a critical hit, it gains a +2 status bonus to attack and damage rolls until the end of its next turn. It can't use reactions while this frenzy lasts.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.tJx9B2e3AET6PbJD]{Effect: Pain Frenzy}
qY4Gqits5ZaytjDY.name: Pain Frenzy

Feral Krooth.name: Feral Krooth
Feral Krooth.npcAllSaves: +4 status to all saves vs. fear

Festering Plague Zombie.description:
Plague zombies are infested with horrible contagions.

A zombie's only desire is to consume the living. Unthinking and ever-shambling harbingers of death, zombies stop only when they're destroyed.

MuiyXm8KyQF57NaW.description: Requirements The zombie has a creature @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}.
MuiyXm8KyQF57NaW.name: Jaws

RhGXKyPEo0bWS5D1.description:
An infected creature can't heal damage it takes from zombie rot until it has been cured of the disease

Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:21]

Stage 1 carrier with no ill effect (1 day)

Stage 2 @Damage[1d6[void]] damage (1 day)

Stage 3 @Damage[1d6[void]] damage (1 day)

Stage 4 @Damage[1d6[void]] damage (1 day)

Stage 5 dead, rising as a plague zombie immediately.
RhGXKyPEo0bWS5D1.name: Zombie Rot

a2pZeef5wn9y5xAA.description: A zombie is permanently @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and can't use reactions.
a2pZeef5wn9y5xAA.name: Slow

Festering Plague Zombie.name: Festering Plague Zombie

32VQUPgFDLArNN9s.description: The sparking zombie has been implanted with tech components that have malfunctioned and are crackling with electricity. A creature that hits the zombie with an unarmed Strike takes @Damage[5[electricity]] damage.
32VQUPgFDLArNN9s.name: Short Circuit

VTtnqCB7pHtTrVJJ.description:
A cybernetic zombie must use this reaction unless its cybernetics are disabled

Trigger The cybernetic zombie is reduced to 0 Hit Points

Effect The zombie's damaged cybernetics explode, dealing @Damage[(3d8+2)[electricity]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[emanation|distance:10]{10-foot radius} (@Check[reflex|dc:19|basic|options:area-effect] save). This ability destroys any technological items on the zombie.
VTtnqCB7pHtTrVJJ.name: Self Destruct

YQi4pEcsJfon1nS3.description: The cybernetics of a cybernetic zombie can be disabled for 1 hour with a successful [[/act disable-device dc=19]] check. A zombie's cybernetics are disabled for 1 hour if it takes any electricity damage. A cybernetic zombie with disabled cybernetics is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and can't use reactions (including self-destruct).
YQi4pEcsJfon1nS3.name: Cybernetics

Foroxicks.description:
Wargs hunt in packs like wolves, but their penchant for taunting victims makes them easy to distinguish from their cousins. Orcs and hobgoblins frequently recruit wargs. Most wargs are amenable to this arrangement, but if food should run out, wargs are more than willing to integrate goblinoid flesh into their diet.

The warg is an intelligent and malevolent wolf that dwells among goblins, hobgoblins, orcs, and violent humanoids.

BQkt9pmzJnmXvZLL.description:
Foroxicks becomes enraged if his silks, golden mirrors, or throne are damaged. He takes a –2 circumstance penalty to his jaws attack, but each hit deals 1 additional point of piercing damage for three rounds as he attacks with uncontrolled fury.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.campaign-effects.Item.ALYd08DB00ZeoHAp]{Effect: Pompous Rage}
BQkt9pmzJnmXvZLL.name: Pompous Rage

VfGIlE5o88e6ZuW6.description: Foroxicks's Strikes deals an extra 1d4 damage to any creature within reach of at least two of his allies.
VfGIlE5o88e6ZuW6.name: Pack Attack

Vg2UnnmNwX8ZkN0y.description: Foroxicks commands an ally to aid him. One ally uses a reaction to move up to their Speed into an open space to flank with Foroxicks.
Vg2UnnmNwX8ZkN0y.name: Do Your Job!

z4Mouf0sgt0pO2Vz.description:
Trigger A creature within reach of the Foroxicks's jaws attacks one of the warg's allies.

Effect Foroxicks makes a jaws Strike against the triggering creature.
z4Mouf0sgt0pO2Vz.name: Avenging Bite

Foroxicks.name: Foroxicks

Foul Font.description: The font is hidden just under the water's surface. It spews foul brown sludge into the pristine waters, leaving them reeking and polluted as they move downstream. It can be reached without swimming, but not without getting wet.
Foul Font.hazardDisable: @Check[nature|dc:17] (trained) to draw upon the suppressed Primal energies of this place to cleanse the font, @Check[religion|dc:23] (expert) to suppress the void energies, @Check[thievery|dc:20] to undo the magic sigils allowing the font to operate; two total successes are required to disable the font.
Foul Font.hazardReset: The foul font deactivates 1 minute after all creatures leave the area but resets immediately thereafter.
Foul Font.hazardRoutine: (2 actions) The foul font uses its actions each turn to spew a single void geyser.
Foul Font.name: Foul Font

8eumTeww6536avGC.description:
Requirements The gargarthezul is on the deck of a ship.

Effect The gargarthezul swings from a nearby rope, moving up to twice its Speed and ignoring any terrain or lack of surface beneath it. It can make a tentacle Strike at any point during this movement.
8eumTeww6536avGC.name: Halyard Swing

QlktgKrcecMqG2Sa.description:
Requirements The gargarthezul's last action was a successful tentacle Strike.

Effect The gargarthezul places a brand on the creature it hit that fills the creature's mind with overwhelming urges towards piracy. The creature doesn't treat anyone as their ally and can't Delay or Ready. They must use all of their actions to attempt to Disarm, or Demoralize, targeting a creature randomly determined by the GM (they may use actions to facilitate their attempts, such as to move to the target or to drop an item so they have a free hand). The duration is based on a @Check[will|dc:17] save. If the creature successfully Disarms or Demoralizes their target, they can attempt a @Check[flat|dc:11] check to recover from Mark of Avarice. The gargarthezul may only have one mark of avarice in effect at any given time. An additional mark placed causes the previous one to fade.

Critical Success The creature becomes temporarily immune for 1 minute.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The mark lasts for 1 round.

Critical Failure The mark lasts for 1 minute.
QlktgKrcecMqG2Sa.name: Mark of Avarice

X6hOrjB6TIyhyMQ5.description: A gargarthezul can't stand to be shown up. The first time each round a creature successfully Demoralizes, Shoves, or Trips a gargarthezul, it takes @Damage[1d6[mental]] damage.
X6hOrjB6TIyhyMQ5.name: Bravado Aversion

jKfNuCn6j4e1lsfR.description:
When a gargarthezul successfully @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.2u915NdUyQan6uKF]{Demoralizes} a foe, it gains 1d6 temporary Hit Points (2d6 on a critical success) that last for 1 minute.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.P8LdA05tK20u98MF]{Effect: Vicious Bluster}

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.Ty2YFxv2EDBOSjxl]{Effect: Vicious Bluster (Critical Success)}
jKfNuCn6j4e1lsfR.name: Vicious Bluster

yRpNZFLbeUdqHQ8H.description: The gargarthezul @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.7blmbDrQFNfdT731]{Shoves} a creature, and Strides after it into the nearest adjacent square if successful. It then makes a tentacle Strike against the creature, using the same multiple attack penalty.
yRpNZFLbeUdqHQ8H.name: Bully

1u7j67eihiSQSeJs.description: The getidline rushes forward and rips a creature away from its standing. It Strides, then @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.PMbdMWc2QroouFGD]{Grapples} a creature. If it successfully Grapples, it then @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.g26YiEIfSHCpLocV]{Constricts} the creature.
1u7j67eihiSQSeJs.name: Rip Away

Igrx0lF2yf3PIAaH.description: A getidline holds on to relationships and refuses to let go. When a creature grabbed by it loses the grabbed condition, the getidline takes @Damage[4d6[mental]] damage.
Igrx0lF2yf3PIAaH.name: Abandonment Vulnerability

L9CuAb7QPpoTtRTt.description:
15 feet.

A getidline subtly influences all living creatures within its aura to focus their attentions on holding to things they care about above all other concerns. When a living, non-demon creature starts its turn in the getidline's aura, it must attempt a @Check[will|dc:21] save. On a failure, the targeted is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1} as it focuses on maintaining its grip on its weapons and gear (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 2} on a critical failure). The elementals are immune to this aura as they don't have possessions.
L9CuAb7QPpoTtRTt.name: Gripping Aura

Ghoul Commando.description:
Retaining their martial skill, these powerful ghouls are not afraid to meet their foe in the open, feeding on the flesh of their fallen opponents to learn their combat abilities.

Few creatures are more ubiquitous to sinister locations such as lonely graveyards and ruined crypts than the flesh-eating undead known as ghouls.

KHysHMKYybPFeqI5.description:
Requirements A @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious} creature is within the ghoul's reach

Effect The ghoul whispers dark thoughts and vile cravings into the creature's ears. The creature must save against the forbidden cravings curse.

Forbidden Cravings (curse) A creature can still eat and drink while sickened by this curse

Saving Throw @Check[will|dc:22|traits:curse]

Stage 1 carrier with no ill effects (1 day)

Stage 2 @Damage[2d6[void]] damage and the target is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} until it consumes raw meat (1 day)

Stage 3 as stage 2

Stage 4 as stage 2 unless the target has consumed raw meat in the past 24 hours, then it takes @Damage[4d6[void]] damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} until it consumes raw meat;

Stage 5 if the creature has eaten raw meat in the past 24 hours, it dies and rises as a ghoul, if not, it returns to stage 4
KHysHMKYybPFeqI5.name: Ghoul Whispers

R9q9hezMY3S2b5ha.description: The ghoul jumps up to half its Speed. This movement doesn't trigger reactions.
R9q9hezMY3S2b5ha.name: Swift Leap

Z7PO71C8UMa9vrP4.description:
Requirements The ghoul is adjacent to the corpse of a creature that died within the last hour.

Effect The ghoul devours a chunk of the corpse and regains @Damage[3d6[healing]] Hit Points.

It can regain Hit Points from any given corpse only once.
Z7PO71C8UMa9vrP4.name: Consume Flesh

dbJMknRXkshhKBXb.description:
[[/r 1d20+13]]{+13} skill modifier

Frequency once per hour

Effect The ghoul calls upon knowledge it retains from one creature it has consumed in the past 7 days. The ghoul attempts a skill check using a skill in which the consumed creature was trained (if it's unclear whether the creature was trained, the GM decides). The ghoul is treated as trained and uses the high skill modifier for the ghoul's level. This takes the same amount of actions or time as usual for the check.

The ghoul can instead automatically learn something specific known by a creature it consumed in the last 7 days, like the location of a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Hidden} treasure or the name of a loved one. The ghoul can do this only once for a given creature, no matter how much of its flesh the ghoul consumed.
dbJMknRXkshhKBXb.name: Grave Knowledge

Ghoul Commando.name: Ghoul Commando

ucptM7OaFP5CpesA.description:
Frequency once per minute

Effect The giant stinkbug turns and sends a spurt of foul liquid from its rear in a @Template[type:cone|distance:10], dealing @Damage[2d6[poison]|options:area-damage] damage with a @Check[reflex|dc:15|basic|options:area-effect,inflicts:sickened] save. On a critical failure, an affected creature is also @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}.
ucptM7OaFP5CpesA.name: Stink Blast

Gluttonous Geode (Quest 22).description:
The vast ranks of earth elementals have been slow to respond to the return of the elemental lords and the Planes of Metal and Wood. These events have not broken the mountains, nor have they blown away the sands.

Earthy Emotions

Earth elementals talk even less than most elementals. They're ponderous, weighing decisions so slowly they can crush the energy from a discussion. Their foremost concern is whether a situation can be endured. Though a rare or resplendent treasure might entice an earth elemental, it's difficult to spur any sense of urgency in them without the presence of an immediate threat.

JQEFb9KA6XUO7dyb.description:
Requirements The geode is attached to a creature

Effect The geode deals @Damage[(1d4+2)[bludgeoning]] damage to the creature it's attached to (@Check[fortitude|dc:17|basic] save).
JQEFb9KA6XUO7dyb.name: Gnaw

iiNeC7jyAcDS6aGh.description: The geode Leaps up to 15 feet and makes a crystal teeth Strike. If it hits a creature larger than itself, it can attach to that creature. Doing so is like Grabbing the creature (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escape} DC 17), but the geode moves with that creature rather than holding it in place. The geode is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} while attached. If the geode is killed or pushed away while attached to a creature, that creature takes @Damage[1[bleed]]{1 persistent bleed} damage. Escaping the attached geode or removing the geode in other ways doesn't cause bleed damage.
iiNeC7jyAcDS6aGh.name: Attach

Gluttonous Geode (Quest 22).name: Gluttonous Geode (Quest 22)

Greased Floor.name: Greased Floor

Greater Kithangian.description: The kithangian—a horrifying amalgam of horse and scorpion also known as a "beast demon"—is a foul fend born of the souls of mortals who abused and tormented animals in life. Kithangians tend to roam wild areas rife with animals to torture, though humanoid settlements with plenty of pets or livestock also make for tantalizing hunting grounds. Uncontested for too long, a kithangian's presence has a corrupting influence on the local fauna, which birth fiendish monstrosities until the demon is vanquished. If it realizes it's being tracked by vengeful druids or demon slayers, a kithangian assumes the shape of an unassuming animal so it can get the jump on its pursuers.

32S5DB2W7IQGpjKR.description: A kithangian's melee Strikes deal an additional 2d6 damage to animals.
32S5DB2W7IQGpjKR.name: Animal Killer

AXIbwimQwwZXY5La.description: Kithangians find kindness to animals revolting. The first time each round that a kithangian sees someone heal or otherwise provide aid to a creature that has the animal trait, the kithangian takes @Damage[3d6[mental]].
AXIbwimQwwZXY5La.name: Animal Kindness Vulnerability

CoQTAk22h5lnU6tR.description:
Frequency once per round;

Requirements The kithangian has a creature @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} in one or both pincers

Effect Barbed tongues slither out of the faces in the kithangian's pincers. The tongues burrow into grabbed creatures and inject their minds with haunting psychic screams. Each grabbed creature takes @Damage[2d8[piercing]] damage and @Damage[2d8[mental]] damage. A creature can try to resist the mental damage by attempting a @Check[will|dc:27|basic] save.
CoQTAk22h5lnU6tR.name: Rasping Tongues

FsQWwjREZfdxra5l.description:
The kithangian can take on the appearance of any Medium or Large animal. This doesn't change its Speed or their attack and damage modif ers with its Strikes, but it might change the damage type its Strikes deal.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.ChangeShape]

ZKaduXctpn6ATVjC.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:27]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[2d6[poison]] damage (2 rounds)

Stage 2 @Damage[2d6[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (2 rounds)

Stage 3 @Damage[3d6[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} (2 rounds)

Gruasha.description:
Shadow giants are natives of the Netherworld, where they have dwelled in perpetual twilight for millennia. They live in familiar groups and uphold a nomadic way of life as they roam across ancestral lands between shadowy forests and misty chasms. These hunter-gatherers pass down lore through oral histories, conduct pilgrimages to unholy ziggurats of black stone, and bathe in the blood of their long-standing foes, including rival shadow giant clans and fiends of the Netherworld intent on enslaving their kind.

Standing 15 feet tall, with gray skin and hair only a shade lighter, shadow giants are fearsome foes with a well-earned reputation as zealous warmongers and ruthless combatants. They rarely interact with outsiders, though they may treat with proven warriors who show the giants the respect and deference they feel they deserve.

Giants are massive humanoid creatures who live in remote regions throughout the world. They vary widely but are united in their hunger, requiring sustenance of their own element along with the feasts one would expect from such a massive humanoid. Although a simple matter for some giants, more esoteric types find this need a harsh reality. While a massive fistful of ice or snow alongside their meal will satisfy a frost giant, shadow giants hunger for the coagulated shadows of the Netherworld.

CFQjHuIFlshnvM7H.description: Shadows extend the giant's chain as they make a spiked chain Strike, increasing their reach to 60 feet for that Strike. If this hits, the target must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:30] save or be teleported to an empty space within the shadow giant's normal reach.
CFQjHuIFlshnvM7H.name: Shadow Chain

PDPYyeFFpfksUoXK.description: The shadow giant gains the effect of the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.3JG1t3T4mWn6vTke]{Blur} spell for 1 minute or until they are exposed to direct sunlight, whichever comes first.
PDPYyeFFpfksUoXK.name: Shadowcloak

WsGuoYeAA0yWHOXE.description: When a shadow giant hits with a melee attack, the target must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:27] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} and take a –1 status penalty to Perception checks involving sight as long as they remain drained. On a critical failure, this condition doesn't heal naturally and can be removed only with magic.
WsGuoYeAA0yWHOXE.name: Pall of Shadow

Gruasha.name: Gruasha

Halfling Shadower.description:
Halflings' keen sight makes them excellent street watchers. Though the job rarely calls for fighting, most street watchers cover themselves head to ankle in whatever armor and weapons they manage to get their hands on.

Despite their small stature, a halfling can prove to be a mighty foe if you find yourself on the wrong side of their frying pan.

48CFcDY5R0rTxFmv.description:
The halfling gains a +2 circumstance bonus when using the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.BlAOM2X92SI6HMtJ]{Seek} action to find @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Hidden} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VRSef5y1LmL2Hkjf]{Undetected} creatures within 30 feet of it.

Whenever the halfling targets a creature that is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} or hidden from them, reduce the DC of the flat check to @Check[flat|dc:3] for a concealed target or @Check[flat|dc:9] for a hidden one.
48CFcDY5R0rTxFmv.name: Keen Eyes

Halfling Shadower.name: Halfling Shadower

Handheld Quaker.description: This small toy-like device has a hidden mechanism meant to be activated by the user, but the centuries have eroded its magical-mechanical components to the point that they activate at the slightest touch.
Handheld Quaker.hazardDisable: @Check[thievery|dc:18] (trained) to deactivate the mechanism; @Check[crafting|dc:16] (trained) to identify and repair the problem components; two successes are required to disable the hazard.
Handheld Quaker.hazardReset: The trap deactivates and resets if 1 minute passes without a creature being within 5' of the handheld quaker.
Handheld Quaker.hazardRoutine:
At its initiative, to determine what the quaker does, roll [[/gmr 1d4]] and consult the following table:

1: No action

2: A small quake: the terrain in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:10] centered on the quaker shakes briefly. A creature in an affected square is knocked @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone} (@Check[reflex|dc:18] save).

3: A medium quake: the terrain within the vault shakes constantly, transforming it into difficult terrain until its next turn. A creature in an affected square is knocked prone and takes @Damage[1d10[bludgeoning]] damage from the fall (@Check[reflex|dc:18|basic] save).

4: A great quake: the terrain within the vault moves in waves, transforming it into greater difficult terrain until its next turn. A creature in an affected square is violently slammed to the ground, knocked prone, and takes @Damage[(1d10+4)[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:20|basic] save).
Handheld Quaker.name: Handheld Quaker

Hatched Shemhazian.description:
Shemhazians rise from the souls of torturers and those who reveled in mutilating the physical bodies of their victims. Standing 35 feet tall, a shemhazian is well equipped with a wide range of claws, pincers, and fangs to continue inflicting such torments on those they encounter.

Shemhazians delight in tormenting mortals, of course, but more than most demons, they revel in sharing the pain with their own kind. Other demons fear and hate shemhazians for this reason, with only the most powerful willing to work with a shemhazian to achieve a shared goal. Even then, the shemhazian is always on the watch for an opportunity to bring pain and suffering to their allies along with any foe.

When a sinful mortal soul is judged and sent on to the Outer Rifts, it can become a deadly fiend—a demon. Demons are living incarnations of sin—be they classic sins like wrath or gluttony, or more "specialized" depravities like an obsession with torture or the act of treason or treachery. Once formed, a demon's driving goals are twofold—the amassing of personal power, and the corruption of mortal souls to cause them to become tainted by sin. In this way demons ensure a never-ending supply of new demons to bolster their ever-growing ranks in the Outer Rifts.

Demons are selfish and self-absorbed creatures, and most firmly believe that mortals only play at being more virtuous than fiends. They enjoy tempting mortals into damnation to both indulge their egos and swell their armies. Like many other fiends, one of the great rewards of this manipulation is fulfilling their hunger for souls. In their eyes, the primary use for these souls is to spawn new demons, who can serve as soldiers, slaves, pawns, or even currency for their more powerful masters.

4TtLSpRhmqV1Dvp1.description:
Trigger A creature within reach of the shemhazian's tail leaves a square during a move action it's using

Effect The shemhazian attempts to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.ge56Lu1xXVFYUnLP]{Trip} the triggering creature. On a success, the creature also takes damage as if the shemhazian had hit with a tail Strike, and if the creature was flying, it falls 30 feet.

The target can attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:33] save to reduce this to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} (or be unaffected on a critical success).
AsXbDxRSKFmiQ6jb.name: Enfeebling Bite

EbuMoQ5idyQJDEXD.name: Paralyzing Gaze

Tk7abWUpvDDV6Qg0.description: A shemhazian's mutilation is a part of them, and they can't bear to see it reversed. The first time each round that a creature heals from damage the shemhazian dealt on their last turn, the demon takes @Damage[3d6[mental]] damage.

If that creature is slowed, it must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:31] save or be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} for 1 round.

A shemhazian can't use this ability against the same creature more than once per round.
aqwHyoUR6cj9y6s8.name: Focused Gaze

Haunted Hollows.description: The spirits of innumerable dryads and peaceful wood elementals, ripped from their bodies as they were turned into furniture, writhe and seethe, lashing out at both living and undead alike.
Haunted Hollows.hazardDisable:
@Check[diplomacy|dc:17] (trained), @Check[nature|dc:17] (trained), or @Check[religion|dc:17] (trained) to set the spirits to rest or @Check[deception|dc:20], @Check[intimidation|dc:20], or @Check[occultism|dc:20] to convince the spirits that their eternal rest is coming soon.

A PC may make a Strike against AC 16 to destroy a single table or chair in the room, this functions as a successful check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.HCl3pzVefiv9ZKQW]{Aid} another PC attempting to disable the haunt; two total successes are required to disable the haunt. If all of the tables and chairs are destroyed, the haunt is temporarily disabled until dawn of the next day.
Haunted Hollows.hazardRoutine: (two actions) The Haunted Hollows haunt uses one table flip Strike or two chair toss Strikes at random creatures in the area, favoring those who are trying to disable the haunt first. The table flip Strikes originate with any table in the room, destroying the table in the process. The chair toss Strikes originate with any chair or bar stool in the room, destroying that object in the process. If the haunt is not disabled, these objects reform and return to their original positions at dawn of the next day.
Haunted Hollows.name: Haunted Hollows

The elegecide lashes out with its trailing dorsal fins, looping them around a target within 15 feet. The target takes @Damage[(1d4+2)[mental]] damage and must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:18|traits:damaging-effect] save.

Success The target takes half damage.

He can Step immediately after the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.QNAVeNKtHA0EUw4X]{Feint} as a free action.
LJVuhBdkTPGokxbc.name: Scoundrel's Feint

Xx4xCuXxoMH9toNK.description: On the first round of combat, creatures that haven't acted yet are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} to the hired hand.
Xx4xCuXxoMH9toNK.name: Surprise Attack

sG5BW8K45THd7AKR.description: The hired hand's Strikes deals an additional 1d6 precision damage to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} creatures.

si0aIAwNtbIf7vdW.description:
Trigger A creature targets the hired hand with an attack, and he can see the attacker

Effect The hired hand deftly dodges out of the way and gains a +2 circumstance bonus to AC against the triggering attack.

Hobgoblin Mercenary.description:
Bands of hobgoblin soldiers typically have at least one archer among their ranks. In smaller groups, the hobgoblin archer also serves as that band's captain.

Hobgoblins may appear to outsiders to be the most civilized of goblinkind, but their civilization is hardly one of kindness and equality-instead, they revel in all that is militaristic, tyrannical, cruel, and destructive. Hobgoblins are singularly devoted to war, and their entire culture is built upon fostering and maintaining conflict while simultaneously proving their superiority in battle. Hobgoblins are highly organized, and they work efficiently and effectively in groups, whether that group is a small raiding party, a roving war band, or a fully regimented army. Hobgoblin rulers require little provocation before declaring war, and more often than not, such wars are waged to gain slaves or territory. Physically, hobgoblins stand about as tall as humans and have gray, ashen skin.

Hobgoblin society is organized along military lines, and every hobgoblin is effectively a member of the army. Each hobgoblin in a community has a rank in the military hierarchy, and individuals are naturally ambitious and obsessed with advancement. Hobgoblins are constantly expected to prove that they're fearless, ruthless, cunning, and strong. Demonstrating such aptitudes is an individual hobgoblin's best hope for promotion through the ranks, but failure leads only to cruel exploitation at the hands of their superiors. Though brutal, hobgoblin society is a true meritocracy, and all hobgoblins, regardless of age, gender, or birth, wield authority and earn respect from their peers based on their skill in battle. Even those individuals who serve in non-combat roles in hobgoblin society-blacksmiths, builders, cooks, messengers, quartermasters, and the like-know that they perform vital jobs that support the larger hobgoblin army, though they rarely rise above the rank of common soldier. Everyone contributes to the larger whole, ensuring that hobgoblin society is the strongest and most efficient it can be, and anyone who fails to do so is culled from the army and this hobgoblin society as dead weight. Hobgoblins don't usually engage in trade with other races, or even with other hobgoblin tribes, preferring to take what they want by force.

9ja6Q3mPufB7rxnt.description: The archer Strides, Steps, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.VMozDqMMuK5kpoX4]{Sneaks}, then Interacts to reload.
9ja6Q3mPufB7rxnt.name: Running Reload

LcpFmBryvzaDNDcL.description:
The hobgoblin archer ignores the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} condition.

Their targets don't benefit from lesser cover, and they reduce the AC bonus from standard cover by 2 against the hobgoblin archer's attack.
LcpFmBryvzaDNDcL.name: Perfect Aim

kMmbg9uYz80oPVxp.description: The first time the archer hits with a crossbow attack in a round, it deals 1d8 extra precision damage.
kMmbg9uYz80oPVxp.name: Crossbow Precision

rWeRpLhEFS7p5VCy.description: When it's adjacent to at least two other allies, the hobgoblin archer gains a +1 circumstance bonus to AC and saving throws. This bonus increases to +2 to Reflex saves against area effects.
rWeRpLhEFS7p5VCy.name: Formation

Hobgoblin Mercenary.name: Hobgoblin Mercenary

Horrible Pond.description: The illusion of a normal, if dirty, pond is broken by clammy hands reaching up from the depths. While they never break the surface, travelers feel compelled to reach for the grasping fingers and willingly walk to their doom.
Horrible Pond.hazardDisable: @Check[deception|dc:28], @Check[diplomacy|dc:28] or @Check[religion|dc:28] (expert) to calm the spirits; two successes required, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (4th rank; counteract DC 28) to dispel the magic.
Horrible Pond.hazardReset: When there are no living humanoids within 30 feet of the pond, the hands recede into the depths and the pond resets.
Horrible Pond.hazardRoutine: (1 action) The pond attempts to Grab all PCs in the water with a [[/gmr 1d20+18 #Athletics]]{+18} Athletics bonus. Any @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained} PCs take @Damage[(4d10+22)[void]|traits:unholy] (unholy) damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:28|basic] save). All PCs within 30 feet must then make a save against Call of the Depths.
Horrible Pond.name: Horrible Pond

Hot Spring Statue.description:
Giant animated statues' increased size and power make them most useful in large vaults, spacious chambers, or outdoor locations. Tasks beyond their capabilities typically require a more advanced construct, not an animated object.

Granted a semblance of life through the use of rituals or other strange magic, animated objects take many forms and serve a variety of uses. A few examples of typical animated objects are listed below. Many of these creatures serve as guardians, surprising unsuspecting adventurers when they suddenly attack. Others serve as idle distractions for the exceptionally rich, simple servants created to handle odd jobs, and the like.

FHYZijWKqxyPWq4b.description: Like normal objects, a giant animated statue has Hardness. This Hardness reduces any damage it takes by an amount equal to the Hardness. Once a giant animated statue is reduced to less than half its Hit Points, or immediately upon being damaged by a critical hit, its construct armor breaks and its Armor Class is reduced to 22.
FHYZijWKqxyPWq4b.name: Construct Armor (Hardness 10)

M203mlcBNFvAqyIJ.description: The statue hinges open, revealing boiling water within it, and then plunges a creature it has @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained} in. The target takes @Damage[3d8[fire],1d8[persistent,fire]] damage.
M203mlcBNFvAqyIJ.name: Boil Alive

v0n7ntTptPAp7TPz.description: The statue is magically powered by the same geothermal power that heats the waters in Maecho's hot springs. Dealing 15 cold damage to the statue cools it off, preventing it from using Boil Alive, removing the fire damage from its ranged attacks, and making it @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for one round, after which the cold water cycles out of the statue and it returns to its usual temperature.
v0n7ntTptPAp7TPz.name: Geothermally Heated

Hot Spring Statue.name: Hot Spring Statue

8eumTeww6536avGC.description:
Requirements The gargarthezul is on the deck of a ship.

Effect The gargarthezul swings from a nearby rope, moving up to twice its Speed and ignoring any terrain or lack of surface beneath it. It can make a tentacle Strike at any point during this movement.
8eumTeww6536avGC.name: Halyard Swing

Jio6rOXycNZ50qmQ.description:
When a gargarthezul successfully @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.2u915NdUyQan6uKF]{Demoralizes} a foe, it gains 1d6 temporary Hit Points (2d6 on a critical success) that last for 1 minute.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.P8LdA05tK20u98MF]{Effect: Vicious Bluster}

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.Ty2YFxv2EDBOSjxl]{Effect: Vicious Bluster (Critical Success)}
Jio6rOXycNZ50qmQ.name: Vicious Bluster

QlktgKrcecMqG2Sa.description:
Requirements The gargarthezul's last action was a successful tentacle Strike.

Effect The gargarthezul places a brand on the creature it hit that fills the creature's mind with overwhelming urges towards piracy. The creature doesn't treat anyone as their ally and can't Delay or Ready. They must use all of their actions to attempt to Disarm, or Demoralize, targeting a creature randomly determined by the GM (they may use actions to facilitate their attempts, such as to move to the target or to drop an item so they have a free hand). The duration is based on a @Check[will|dc:15] save. If the creature successfully Disarms or Demoralizes their target, they can attempt a @Check[flat|dc:11] check to recover from Mark of Avarice. The gargarthezul may only have one mark of avarice in effect at any given time. An additional mark placed causes the previous one to fade.

Critical Success The creature becomes temporarily immune for 1 minute.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The mark lasts for 1 round.

Critical Failure The mark lasts for 1 minute.
QlktgKrcecMqG2Sa.name: Mark of Avarice

X6hOrjB6TIyhyMQ5.description: A gargarthezul can't stand to be shown up. The first time each round a creature successfully Demoralizes, Shoves, or Trips a gargarthezul, it takes @Damage[1d6[mental]] damage.
X6hOrjB6TIyhyMQ5.name: Bravado Aversion

yRpNZFLbeUdqHQ8H.description: The gargarthezul @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.7blmbDrQFNfdT731]{Shoves} a creature, and Strides after it into the nearest adjacent square if successful. It then makes a tentacle Strike against the creature, using the same multiple attack penalty.
yRpNZFLbeUdqHQ8H.name: Bully

Incensed Captain Fraez.description:
The captain is the ultimate authority on a vessel, responsible for the livelihood and well-being of everyone on the ship.

Adventurers may need passage on a swift vessel, or they might face danger from raiders at sea or in coastal settlements.

5iTqDt4fDSnYuJIg.description:
The captain makes two Strikes, one with their rapier and one with their main-gauche (in either order). If both Strikes hit, the ship captain can attempt to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.Dt6B1slsBy8ipJu9]{Disarm} the target.

Their multiple attack penalty increases only after all the attacks are made.
5iTqDt4fDSnYuJIg.name: Dual Disarm

FMRFRcuXn2QHFX2v.description: When Captain Fraez rolls a success on a Will save against a fear effect, they get a critical success instead. In addition, anytime they gain the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened} condition, reduce its value by 1.
FMRFRcuXn2QHFX2v.name: Bravery

OjePIuXOLgAEb4RG.description:
The captain orders their shipmates to fight without mercy. All allied creatures of equal or lower level within 20 feet of the ship captain gain a+1 status bonus to attack rolls and damage rolls until the end of the ship captain's next turn.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.TjRZbd52qWPjTbNT]{Effect: No Quarter!}
OjePIuXOLgAEb4RG.name: No Quarter!

Incensed Captain Fraez.name: Incensed Captain Fraez

Intense Treacherous Scree.description: The footing on this sloped ground appears to be stable at first glance, but the tiny rocks that cover it are loosely packed and prone to slipping.
Intense Treacherous Scree.name: Intense Treacherous Scree

kmVwWgYwjkNzlgyA.description:
1 to 3

Requirements Sotroz is within 30 feet of a bonded cage that has a living small or tiny animal inside of it

Effect Sotroz steals the life-force of the trapped animal, killing it instantly and gaining one of the following abilities depending on the number of actions spent.

  • Gate Jump 1 Sotroz teleports to a space within any ritual circle in their sanctum.
  • Transmute Death 2 Sotroz casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.Jmxru8zMdYMRuO5n]{Vision of Death} on a living target within 60 feet of their current location.
  • Life Steal 3 Sotroz casts a 4th-rank @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.N1Z1oLPdBxaSgrEE]{Vampiric Feast} on a living target within 30 feet of their current location.
kmVwWgYwjkNzlgyA.name: Ritual Sacrifice

pc92OYRUY6QlEulj.description:
Frequency once per round

Sotroz applies their arcane knowledge to a problem in a unique way, allowing them to roll any skill check using Arcana, even if they are untrained.
pc92OYRUY6QlEulj.name: Arcane Secrets

Jinkin (Quest 20) (1-2).description:
Jinkins are sadistic tinkers who steal and sabotage items and take great pride in their power to curse precious objects. They hold grudges and create convoluted plans for revenge when they feel slighted, such as when a creature dares to remove one of their curses. Rarely content to wreak simple mayhem, jinkins also take immense pleasure in torture and murder, though they prefer to lead victims into traps designed to capture or incapacitate rather than just kill them outright. Deep pits are a preferred method, since victims who survive their fall face a slow death from starvation and thirst while jinkins gather at the edge of pits to tease and torment them.

Gremlins are cruel fey tricksters and saboteurs who have fully acclimated to life in the Universe, finding distinct niches for their inventive destructiveness. Nearly all gremlins delight in ruining or breaking things, whether it's something physical like a device or vehicle or something intangible such as an alliance or relationship. A gremlin's greatest joy is watching the collapse of complex creations, preferably after the slightest, carefully targeted nudge from the gremlin. Gremlins tend to denigrate, bully, or even slaughter their lesser kin, particularly mitflits, whom stronger gremlins derisively call "baggies."

fHam88iT0r3U5tcl.description: A group of six jinkins can work together for an hour to imbue an item with a curse at a range of 60 feet. While this process is lengthy, it's also unobtrusive and can be performed while @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.XMcnh4cSI32tljXa]{Hiding}. Jinkins prefer to use this ability on magic items. The curse makes the item unreliable (@Check[flat|dc:5] check or waste any action to Interact with or Activate the item), adds a bizarre requirement to use the item, or imparts some other curse of a similar caliber.
fHam88iT0r3U5tcl.name: Tinker

oObpBdGWzojxRdfS.description: The jinkin deals 1d6 extra precision damage to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} creatures.
oObpBdGWzojxRdfS.name: Sneak Attack

Jinkin (Quest 20) (1-2).name: Jinkin (Quest 20) (1-2)

King Rimesnap.description:
"True" twigjacks, as they consider themselves, are found in wild forests alongside the fey they idolize.

Maladjusted forest denizens, twigjacks form from the cruel and prankish combination of fey and the very woods in which they reside. A twigjack's body is made up of prickly brambles woven with vines. Shaggy, mossy growth, not unlike hair, tops a twigjack's head. Its mouth is just a canyon of splintered and broken sticks bisecting its face. Leaves and sprigs of new growth randomly sprout from the creature's body. Many dense forests on Golarion have at least a handful of twigjacks living in the undergrowth.

While truculent and violent, twigjacks care deeply for what they consider to be their forests. These creatures harass outsiders who delve deep into their wooded domains, forcing back even the most determined explorers, foresters, and travelers, especially when those intruders cut roads through the forest. However, they are not terribly territorial when it comes to other forest creatures. When sylvan creatures, especially fey, rally against an outside threat, twigjacks in the area eagerly arrive to fight, even if they were not invited.

1abnSJGdHEvG6Lyl.description:
Requirements Rimesnap is in undergrowth

Effect Rimesnap scrambles into the undergrowth and instantly teleports to a square of undergrowth within 60 feet. This movement doesn't trigger reactions.
1abnSJGdHEvG6Lyl.name: Bramble Jump

dOcDYCNGkTD6GGcZ.description: Rimesnap sprays a volley of frozen pine needles from their body in a @Template[type:cone|distance:15], dealing @Damage[4d6[piercing],1d6[cold]|options:area-damage]{4d6 piercing and 1d6 cold} damage (@Check[reflex|dc:21|basic|options:area-effect] save). Rimesnap can't use Pine spray again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Pine spray]]{1d4 rounds}.
dOcDYCNGkTD6GGcZ.name: Pine Spray

King Rimesnap.name: King Rimesnap

Lenore Toriasti.description:
Vampire counts rule their demesnes and subjects through a mix of fear and cruelty.

Vampires are undead creatures that feed on the blood of the living.

AVpXnwBBGoOo68pw.description: Lenore turns into a cloud of vapor, as the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.V8wXOsoejQhe6CyG]{Vapor Form} spell, or back to her normal form. She loses fast healing while turned to mist. She can remain in this form indefinitely.
AVpXnwBBGoOo68pw.name: Turn to Mist

AWS8p85NHI3IGL2n.description: Lenore can cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.OsOhx3TGIZ7AhD0P]{Dominate} at will as a divine innate spell (DC 22). Casting it requires staring into the target's eyes, giving the spell the visual trait. Fully destroying Lenore ends the domination, but merely reducing her to 0 HP is insufficient to break the spell.
AWS8p85NHI3IGL2n.name: Dominate

KESgZ7EFPclSlLY8.description:
Requirements A @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious}, or willing creature is within Lenore's reach

Effect Lenore sinks her fangs into that creature to drink their blood. This requires an Athletics check against the victim's Fortitude DC if the victim is grabbed and is automatic for any of the other conditions. The victim is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} and Lenore regains 10 HP. Drinking Blood from a creature that's already drained doesn't restore any HP to Lenore but increases the victim's drained value by 1, killing the victim when it reaches @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 5}. She can also consume blood that's been emptied into a vessel for sustenance but gains no HP from doing so.

A victim's drained condition decreases by 1 per week. A blood transfusion, which requires a successful @Check[medicine|dc:20] check and sufficient blood or a blood donor, reduces the drain by 1 after 10 minutes.
KESgZ7EFPclSlLY8.name: Drink Blood

QpzMidSalFaHGivw.description:
The vampire transforms into one of its animal forms or back into its normal form. Most vampires can turn into a bat, but some can turn into a different creature, such as a rat or a wolf.

  • Giant Bat
    • Senses echolocation 40 feet,
    • Speed 20 feet, fly 30 feet,
    • Melee fangs +15 Damage 1d8+9 piercing

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.ChangeShape]
QpzMidSalFaHGivw.name: Change Shape

TjOmyfilNvHKI58M.description: Lenore's presence brings forth creatures of the night to do their master's bidding. These typically include @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.pathfinder-monster-core.Actor.6wPW2dvpt86Ou6bL]{rat swarms}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.pathfinder-monster-core.Actor.2mg30nJR6P3HJDSd]{bat swarms}, and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.pathfinder-monster-core.Actor.BN5Lb6IsQ9Wyu3rL]{wolves} but can include other creatures. Lenore can give telepathic orders to these creatures as long as they're within 100 feet, but they can't communicate back.
TjOmyfilNvHKI58M.name: Children of the Night

XfOwixhCw3iiUdHi.description: Lenore gains a +1 circumstance bonus to attack rolls with her +1 chain sword if she has already attempted to attack a different target this turn using this weapon.
XfOwixhCw3iiUdHi.name: Chain Attacks

iuyYNQtDMprDDoZH.description:
Trigger Lenore is reduced to 0 HP

Effect The vampire uses Turn to Mist. They can take move actions to move toward their coffin even though they're at 0 HP. While at 0 HP in this form, the vampire is unaffected by further damage. They automatically return to their corporeal form, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious}, if they reach their coffin or after 2 hours, whichever comes first.
iuyYNQtDMprDDoZH.name: Mist Escape

Lenore Toriasti.name: Lenore Toriasti
Lenore Toriasti.npcHp: coffin restoration, fast healing 7, void healing

Lenore Toriasti (7-8).description:
Vampire counts rule their demesnes and subjects through a mix of fear and cruelty.

Vampires are undead creatures that feed on the blood of the living.

AVpXnwBBGoOo68pw.description: Lenore turns into a cloud of vapor, as the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.V8wXOsoejQhe6CyG]{Vapor Form} spell, or back to her normal form. She loses fast healing while turned to mist. She can remain in this form indefinitely.
AVpXnwBBGoOo68pw.name: Turn to Mist

AWS8p85NHI3IGL2n.description: Lenore can cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.OsOhx3TGIZ7AhD0P]{Dominate} at will as a divine innate spell (DC 24). Casting it requires staring into the target's eyes, giving the spell the visual trait. Fully destroying Lenore ends the domination, but merely reducing her to 0 HP is insufficient to break the spell.
AWS8p85NHI3IGL2n.name: Dominate

A victim's drained condition decreases by 1 per week. A blood transfusion, which requires a successful @Check[medicine|dc:20] check and sufficient blood or a blood donor, reduces the drain by 1 after 10 minutes.

Trigger Lenore is reduced to 0 HP

Effect The vampire uses Turn to Mist. They can take move actions to move toward their coffin even though they're at 0 HP. While at 0 HP in this form, the vampire is unaffected by further damage. They automatically return to their corporeal form, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious}, if they reach their coffin or after 2 hours, whichever comes first.
