Soaring Nilith.description:
The sleek, dark niliths resemble hairless, emaciated tree sloths. These creatures are intensely dangerous and fearsome, with glowing red eyes, wicked claws, and mouths full of needlelike teeth. Niliths feed off the emotions, fears, and flesh of the living, and folktales posit that those who have nightmares of these creatures are fated to one day be eaten by them. Niliths draw intense joy from tormenting sapient creatures, often focusing their predations on the pious and the just, from whom they draw forth their most basic fears and worst thoughts and revel in their victims' subsequent terror. More often than not, these despicable manipulators wish to drive their victims into madness and even to suicide. Most niliths lack the patience to spend too much time fully tearing down an individual, and when a nilith tires of its current plaything and becomes bored with its particular thoughts and fears, it murders the quarry before feeding on its flesh and moving onto the next victim.

Niliths are actually extensions of much deadlier creatures that dwell in a distant dimension beyond dreams—in a way, niliths are little more than remote feeding machines for the unknown alien entities to which they are connected. Scholars and dimensional travelers have attempted to uncover the exact mechanisms of this mysterious connection, but they have yet to decipher the truth. Indeed, many who investigate the nature of a nilith's bond are driven to madness before getting anywhere close. The odd connection to otherworldly beings might help explain the longevity of these creatures, as it is believed that niliths can live for thousands of years.

Thankfully for others, niliths are solitary creatures that hate the company of their own kind, likely because these harbingers of nightmares have no wish to taste the horrors they bring to others.

LuxUX599os0xTuFk.description:
Requirements The nilith has a creature @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}

Effect The nilith reaches into the mind of the grabbed creature and implants disjointed images of the victim's worst fears and nightmares. The grabbed creature takes @Damage[6d6[mental]] damage with a @Check[will|dc:31|basic] save. On a critical failure, the target is also affected as though by @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5BbU1V6wGSGbrmRD]{Never Mind}, and it must attempt a second Will save against that effect.
LuxUX599os0xTuFk.name: Mind Crush

Soaring Nilith.name: Soaring Nilith

Soggy Zombie Hulk.description:
These towering horrors rise from monstrous, gigantic corpses.

A zombie's only desire is to consume the living. Unthinking and ever-shambling harbingers of death, zombies stop only when they're destroyed.

DTXq4teaiLU9haNE.description: The zombie hulk makes two hunk of wet meat Strikes against different targets within its reach.
DTXq4teaiLU9haNE.name: Wide Swing

TBlBPLZKvFBHjjgU.description: A zombie is permanently slowed 1 and can't use reactions.
TBlBPLZKvFBHjjgU.name: Slow

iTAZj4rMOPRWWJDP.description: A soggy zombie hulk can throw Medium or smaller corpses at foes. They can also throw Medium or smaller zombies for this purpose, who take just as much damage as the target they hit. A zombie that survives being thrown falls @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.
iTAZj4rMOPRWWJDP.name: Corpse Throwing

r1b8kduvauTdVd36.description: A creature hit by the soggy zombie hulk's hunk of wet meat or squelchy corpse Strike must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:22] save, becoming @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} on a failure (or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} on a critical failure). A creature that critically succeeds becomes temporarily immune for 1 hour.
r1b8kduvauTdVd36.name: Moldy Meat

Soggy Zombie Hulk.name: Soggy Zombie Hulk

Somewhat Haunted Hollows.description: The spirits of innumerable dryads and peaceful wood elementals, ripped from their bodies as they were turned into furniture, writhe and seethe, lashing out at both living and undead alike.
Somewhat Haunted Hollows.hazardDisable:
@Check[diplomacy|dc:14] (trained), @Check[nature|dc:14] (trained), or @Check[religion|dc:14] (trained) to set the spirits to rest or @Check[deception|dc:17], @Check[intimidation|dc:17], or @Check[occultism|dc:17] to convince the spirits that their eternal rest is coming soon.

A PC may make a Strike against AC 13 to destroy a single table or chair in the room, this functions as a successful check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.HCl3pzVefiv9ZKQW]{Aid} another PC attempting to disable the haunt; two total successes are required to disable the haunt. If all of the tables and chairs are destroyed, the haunt is temporarily disabled until dawn of the next day.
Somewhat Haunted Hollows.hazardRoutine: (two actions) The Haunted Hollows haunt uses table flip or chair toss Strikes at different creatures in the area, favoring those who are trying to disable the haunt first, but otherwise choosing randomly. The table flip Strikes originate with any table in the room, destroying the table in the process. The chair toss Strikes originate with any chair or bar stool in the room, destroying that object in the process. If the haunt is not disabled, these objects reform and return to their original positions at dawn of the next day.
Somewhat Haunted Hollows.name: Somewhat Haunted Hollows

kmVwWgYwjkNzlgyA.description:
1 to 3

Requirements Sotroz is within 30 feet of a bonded cage that has a living small or tiny animal inside of it

Effect Sotroz steals the life-force of the trapped animal, killing it instantly and gaining one of the following abilities depending on the number of actions spent.

  • Gate Jump 1 Sotroz teleports to a space within any ritual circle in their sanctum.
  • Transmute Death 2 Sotroz casts @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.Jmxru8zMdYMRuO5n]{Vision of Death} on a living target within 60 feet of their current location.
  • Life Steal 3 Sotroz casts a 4th-rank @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.N1Z1oLPdBxaSgrEE]{Vampiric Feast} on a living target within 30 feet of their current location.
kmVwWgYwjkNzlgyA.name: Ritual Sacrifice

pc92OYRUY6QlEulj.description:
Frequency once per round

Sotroz applies their arcane knowledge to a problem in a unique way, allowing them to roll any skill check using Arcana, even if they are untrained.
pc92OYRUY6QlEulj.name: Arcane Secrets

VTtnqCB7pHtTrVJJ.description:
A cybernetic zombie must use this reaction unless its cybernetics are disabled

Trigger The cybernetic zombie is reduced to 0 Hit Points

Effect The zombie's damaged cybernetics explode, dealing @Damage[(3d8+2)[electricity]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[emanation|distance:10]{10-foot radius} (@Check[reflex|dc:19|basic|options:area-effect] save). This ability destroys any technological items on the zombie.
VTtnqCB7pHtTrVJJ.name: Self Destruct

YQi4pEcsJfon1nS3.description: The cybernetics of a cybernetic zombie can be disabled for 1 hour with a successful [[/act disable-device dc=19]] check. A zombie's cybernetics are disabled for 1 hour if it takes any electricity damage. A cybernetic zombie with disabled cybernetics is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and can't use reactions (including self-destruct).
YQi4pEcsJfon1nS3.name: Cybernetics

Sparking Oozeshardling Node.description: A lump of bluish ooze shot through with what look like tiny silver shavings of metal. Once it has been activated, it glows with arcs of electricity that leap out at nearby targets.
Sparking Oozeshardling Node.hazardDisable: Two successful @Check[arcana|dc:23] or @Check[occultism|dc:23] (trained) checks on the oozeshardling to disperse its power, or @Check[acrobatics|dc:25] or @Check[thievery|dc:25] (expert) to remove the flecks of empowering warshard from within the oozeshardling. A failed Acrobatics or Thievery check to disable an oozeshardling results in the creature attempting the check taking @Damage[1d6[acid]] damage (@Damage[2d6[acid]] on a critical failure).
Sparking Oozeshardling Node.hazardReset: The oozeshardling node collapses and melds back into the oozeshard after 1 minute, or disappears entirely if the oozeshard is slain.
Sparking Oozeshardling Node.hazardRoutine: (3 actions) The oozeshardling uses its first action to make an electric spark Strike against one random non-ooze creature within range, its second action is used to move straight in a random cardinal direction (roll [[/gmr 1d4 #Direction]] to determine the direction), and its third action to make a second electric spark Strike against a different random non-ooze creature within range. The oozeshardling doesn't take a multiple attack penalty.
Sparking Oozeshardling Node.name: Sparking Oozeshardling Node

Sparking Plague Zombie.description:
Plague zombies are infested with horrible contagions.

A zombie's only desire is to consume the living. Unthinking and ever-shambling harbingers of death, zombies stop only when they're destroyed.

MuiyXm8KyQF57NaW.description: Requirements The zombie has a creature @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}.
MuiyXm8KyQF57NaW.name: Jaws

RhGXKyPEo0bWS5D1.description:
An infected creature can't heal damage it takes from zombie rot until it has been cured of the disease

Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:22]

Stage 1 carrier with no ill effect (1 day)

Stage 2 @Damage[1d6[void]] damage (1 day)

Stage 3 @Damage[1d6[void]] damage (1 day)

Stage 4 @Damage[1d6[void]] damage (1 day)

Stage 5 dead, rising as a plague zombie immediately.
RhGXKyPEo0bWS5D1.name: Zombie Rot

a2pZeef5wn9y5xAA.description: A zombie is permanently @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and can't use reactions.
a2pZeef5wn9y5xAA.name: Slow

jrezD2WfpCIWM81y.description: The sparking zombie's broken implanted tech crackles with electricity. A creature that hits the zombie with an unarmed Strike takes @Damage[5[electricity]] damage.
jrezD2WfpCIWM81y.name: Short Circuit

Sparking Plague Zombie.name: Sparking Plague Zombie

Sparking Zombie Brute.description:
Necromantic augmentations have granted this zombie increased size and power.

A zombie's only desire is to consume the living. Unthinking and ever-shambling harbingers of death, zombies stop only when they're destroyed.

TtcFIJZjrZ4Vaaml.description: A zombie is permanently @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and can't use reactions.
TtcFIJZjrZ4Vaaml.name: Slow

mv6rZRqHsuHVcwzP.description: The sparking zombie brute has been implanted with tech components that have malfunctioned and are crackling with electricity. A creature that hits the sparking zombie brute with an unarmed Strike takes @Damage[5[electricity]] damage.
mv6rZRqHsuHVcwzP.name: Short Circuit

Sparking Zombie Brute.name: Sparking Zombie Brute

Spiders' Hunting Pit.description: Loose debris covers a patch of what appears as solid ground in a 10 feet by 5 feet area. It's actually covering thin webbing strung over a 20 foot pit.
Spiders' Hunting Pit.hazardDisable: @Check[thievery|dc:18] (trained) to deconstruct the webbing or @Check[acrobatics|dc:20] to pull the webbing apart without getting trapped or hit by rocks.
Spiders' Hunting Pit.name: Spiders' Hunting Pit

DFPsSZ8l3eCLpPpz.description: The spirit hound howls, forcing each living creature within 30 feet to attempt a @Check[will|dc:15] save. On a failure, the creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 3} on a critical failure). On a success, the creature is temporarily immune to this hound's frightful moan for 1 minute.
DFPsSZ8l3eCLpPpz.name: Frightful Moan

fwosUmgcZMQQ7SZz.description: The spirit hound's Strikes deal 1d4 extra damage to creatures within the reach of at least two of its allies.
fwosUmgcZMQQ7SZz.name: Pack Attack

kOINPt7Bte5sDHSt.description: The spirit hound returns with the Caretaker.
kOINPt7Bte5sDHSt.name: Rejuvenation

Sticky Webbing.description: Fine, sticky threads of spiders' silk are strung across their lair.
Sticky Webbing.hazardDisable: @Check[survival|dc:15] or @Check[thievery|dc:15] to carefully remove the strands.
Sticky Webbing.name: Sticky Webbing

Sudden Drop.description: A portion of Manaket's sewer system is under construction and has been left covered by only a few planks of wood since the Godsrain. After two weeks of wear, they're ready to collapse.
Sudden Drop.hazardDisable: If all the PCs succeed on a Perception check against the Stealth DC to spot the hazard, they're able to detour around the weakened boards without triggering it. There's not enough time for PCs who succeed on this check to warn PCs who fail.
Sudden Drop.name: Sudden Drop

Tempestuous Koi Egg.description: A raging storm covers the mountain lake as spring water levitates from the lake to fall back down in a driving spiral of steaming rain. In the depths of the storm, barely visible, is a tiny koi egg surrounded by three bands of water.
Tempestuous Koi Egg.hazardDisable: @Check[arcana|dc:29], @Check[religion|dc:29], @Check[nature|dc:29], or @Check[occultism|dc:29] to purify the magic corrupting the ascension ritual, or @Check[diplomacy|dc:32] or @Check[performance|dc:32] to soothe the spirit within the koi egg and give it the strength to fight off the corruption itself; four total successes are required to purify the ritual, each of the first three successes purifying one ring of water and the final one halting the ritual itself. If the cursed comb has not been removed from the ritual site, then succeeding on this final check merely halts the ritual; if the cursed comb has been removed from the ritual site, then succeeding on this final check completes the ascension ritual.
Tempestuous Koi Egg.hazardReset: The turbulent koi egg can attempt to hatch again, restarting the ascension ritual, after 1000 years of Xalreonshin's care.
Tempestuous Koi Egg.hazardRoutine: (1 action) Torrential water descends from the sky, taking the shape of a dragon that smashes into one creature within 60 feet of the egg. The dragon always targets the creature that is closest to the egg, dealing @Damage[2d12[bludgeoning],2d12[fire]]{2d12 bludgeoning damage and 2d12 fire} damage in a spray of boiling water (@Check[fortitude|dc:28] save). Creatures that fail the save are pushed 10 feet away. Creatures that have the earth trait, are carrying an item with the earth trait, or are otherwise strongly tied to elemental earth (such as an earth elemental sorcerer or kineticist) get the result one degree of success better than the outcome of their save, as the power of elemental earth overcomes water.
Tempestuous Koi Egg.name: Tempestuous Koi Egg

U405VDoNIkMc9Zva.description: The Caretaker possess an object of size Large or smaller within 20 feet, making it an animated object (maximum level 1). If the target object is being held by a creature, the bearer can attempt a @Check[will|dc:16] save to prevent the possession. The possession ends when the object is destroyed or the Caretaker leaves it. At this point, the Caretaker reappears in the object's square and can't Inhabit an Object again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Inhabit an Object]]{1d4 rounds}.
U405VDoNIkMc9Zva.name: Inhabit Object

z294ZgeVIeaVpYTW.description: When defeated, The Caretaker returns in 1 hour, unless he is released with a @Check[religion|dc:22] check or convinced that the PCs are friendly with a @Check[diplomacy|dc:16] check.
z294ZgeVIeaVpYTW.name: Rejuvenation

The Elite Appraiser.description:
Neither human nor beast yet resembling both, yeongno (yeong-no) are creatures that once were denizens of heaven but were cast out, down to the mortal Universe, due to their own greed. Yeongno claim to have once been celestial dragons and wear elongated dragon masks with full-body wraps decorated with scale patterns in honor of this claim—though no one has been able to confirm the veracity of this belief. As they wander, they hold a willow pipe in their mouths, producing a distinct "bibi" sound that often heralds their appearance.

Despite their reputation as monsters who eat people, yeongno are welcomed by the poor and oppressed, who see the creatures as wise and just. Yeongno believe that by eating 100 wealthy individuals who abuse their wealth or who accumulated their wealth by underhanded or exploitative means, they can atone for their own greed, allowing them to ascend back into heaven. A corrupt and greedy individual can escape their fate of being eaten by a yeongno by giving away all of their wealth and agreeing to be transformed into a pig for one year. If the person can endure one year living as a pig in the care of a household they once harmed, the yeongno will spare them.

6eug6ysw8yCw92jm.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect A target creature within 30 feet must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:25] save or gain the effects of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.dN8QBNuTiaBHCKUe]{Cursed Metamorphosis}, being polymorphed into a pig whose girth is determined by the target's wealth. After 24 hours, the target can end this effect using a Dismiss action, at which point the yeongno becomes aware that the effect has ended. A yeongno can use Fortune's Favor only if no targets are currently under its effects.
6eug6ysw8yCw92jm.name: Fortune's Favor

nHkmmECcNb37nfCM.description: The yeongno can detect the presence, location, and approximate value of gold within 120 feet.
nHkmmECcNb37nfCM.name: Goldsense (Precise) 120 feet

pO7jeDvpQCsZJiE4.description:
Requirements The target is carrying at least 100 gp worth of precious metals

Effect The yeongno crushes a creature it can see with the weight of their wealth. Apparitions of gold coins approximating the wealth of the target materialize and pummel the target from all sides. The target attempts a @Check[will|dc:25] save.

Critical Success The target is unaffected.

Success The target is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for 1 round.

Failure The target takes @Damage[3d6[persistent,mental]] damage and is slowed 1 as long as the damage continues. The effect immediately ends if they're carrying less than 100 gp worth of precious metals.

Critical Failure As failure, except any flat checks to remove the persistent damage automatically fail.
pO7jeDvpQCsZJiE4.name: Money is Pain

The Elite Appraiser.name: The Elite Appraiser

The Heartwood Rots.description:
Vampires use their servitor pawns for infiltration and reconnaissance.

Vampires are undead creatures that feed on the blood of the living.

1jREnmv7xdTiRRHp.description: The Heartwood Rots deals 1d6 extra precision damage to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} creatures.
1jREnmv7xdTiRRHp.name: Sneak Attack

hn5GBufYeA5C1oOg.description:
Requirement A @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious}, or willing creature is within the vampire's reach.

Effect The vampire sinks its fangs into that creature to drink its blood. This requires an @Check[athletics|defense:fortitude] check against the victim's Fortitude DC if the victim is grabbed and is automatic for any of the other conditions.

The victim is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} and the vampire regains @Damage[5[healing]]{5 HP}, gaining any excess HP as temporary Hit Points. Drinking Blood from a creature that's already drained doesn't restore any HP to the vampire but increases the victim's drained value by 1, killing the victim when it reaches drained 5. A vampire can also consume blood that's been emptied into a vessel for sustenance, but it gains no HP from doing so.

A victim's drained condition decreases by 1 per week. A blood transfusion, which requires a @Check[medicine|dc:20|name:Blood Transfusion] check and sufficient blood or a blood donor, reduces the drain by 1 after 10 minutes.
hn5GBufYeA5C1oOg.name: Drink Blood

tfYmL4tSNRyScITd.description: When The Heartwood Rots dies, a burst of primal void energy explodes from her body, restoring @Damage[2d8[healing,void]]{2d8} Hit Points to each undead fungi or plant creature in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:30] and killing all natural plants, though merely causing discomfort to creatures with the plant trait. This area is filled with rotten vegetation, becoming difficult terrain.
tfYmL4tSNRyScITd.name: Rotten Burst

The Heartwood Rots.name: The Heartwood Rots
The Heartwood Rots.npcHp: coffin restoration, fast healing 5, void healing

Db3TuNZJTYfa0KY5.description: The Husk of Deskari can see through the eyes of each insect in the swarms infesting its body or those created by its breath weapon. This grants the Husk of Deskari All-Around Vision.
Db3TuNZJTYfa0KY5.name: Swarmsense

QyLMSolqcTIHGUvt.description: The droning buzz of locusts fills the air and mingles with the rasping, screeching sounds of the Husk's carapace plates grinding as it moves. Any creature that begins its turn or moves within 60 feet of the Husk of Deskari must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:33] save or be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}. After attempting the save a creature is immune to the effects of cacophony for 1 minute. On a critical failure, a creature is only immune for 1 round.
QyLMSolqcTIHGUvt.name: Cacophony

XgyTwElt0efdZee1.description: Once the Husk of Deskari has been reduced to 160 hp the surviving locusts retreat inside the Husk rather than surrounding it. At this point the Disgorge Swarm aura ceases to function, the Husk loses its weakness to splash effects and area of effect attacks, and any creature still taking persistent damage from this effect automatically succeeds on their next flat check to remove it.
XgyTwElt0efdZee1.name: Locust Horde

vVMdKgyTWynyRuD5.description:
Millions of fiendish locusts swarm out of the Husk of Deskari, surrounding it in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:30]. The emanation moves with the Husk and remains until removed by Locust Horde. Any creature that enters or begins its turn in the emanation must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:36] save, with effects based on the results of the save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature takes @Damage[2d8[piercing]|options:area-damage] damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} for 1 round.

Failure The creature takes @Damage[4d8[piercing]|options:area-damage] damage and is clumsy 1 for 1 minute.

Critical Failure The creature takes @Damage[8d8[piercing]|options:area-damage] damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2} for one minute.
vVMdKgyTWynyRuD5.name: Disgorge Swarm

Db3TuNZJTYfa0KY5.description: The Husk of Deskari can see through the eyes of each insect in the swarms infesting its body or those created by its breath weapon. This grants the Husk of Deskari All-Around Vision.
Db3TuNZJTYfa0KY5.name: Swarmsense

QyLMSolqcTIHGUvt.description: The droning buzz of locusts fills the air and mingles with the rasping, screeching sounds of the Husk's carapace plates grinding as it moves. Any creature that begins its turn or moves within 60 feet of the Husk of Deskari must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:37] save or be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}. After attempting the save a creature is immune to the effects of cacophony for 1 minute. On a critical failure, a creature is only immune for 1 round.
QyLMSolqcTIHGUvt.name: Cacophony

XgyTwElt0efdZee1.description: Once the Husk of Deskari has been reduced to 200 hp the surviving locusts retreat inside the Husk rather than surrounding it. At this point the Disgorge Swarm aura ceases to function, the Husk loses its weakness to splash effects and area of effect attacks, and any creature still taking persistent damage from this effect automatically succeeds on their next flat check to remove it.
XgyTwElt0efdZee1.name: Locust Horde

vVMdKgyTWynyRuD5.description:
Millions of fiendish locusts swarm out of the Husk of Deskari, surrounding it in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:30]. The swarm moves with the Husk and remains until removed by Locust Horde. Any creature that enters or begins its turn in the emanation must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:37] save, with effects based on the results of the save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature takes @Damage[2d8[piercing]|options:area-damage] damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} for 1 round.

Failure The creature takes @Damage[4d8[piercing]|options:area-damage] damage and is clumsy 1 for 1 minute.

Critical Failure The creature takes @Damage[8d8[piercing]|options:area-damage] damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2} for one minute.
vVMdKgyTWynyRuD5.name: Disgorge Swarm

Thorns of the Rose Pit.description: Decorated smooth-hewn flagstone flooring gives way along hidden seams to a 20-foot square, 25-foot-deep pit festooned with spikes and blades of petrified wood in the darkness below.
Thorns of the Rose Pit.hazardDisable: @Check[thievery|dc:20] (trained) to disable the trap door mechanism
Thorns of the Rose Pit.hazardReset: Creatures can still fall into the trap, but the trap door must be reset manually for the trap to become hidden again.
Thorns of the Rose Pit.name: Thorns of the Rose Pit

Thorns of the Rose Pit (5-6).description: Decorated smooth-hewn flagstone flooring gives way along hidden seams to a 20-foot square, 25-foot-deep pit festooned with spikes and blades of petrified wood in the darkness below.
Thorns of the Rose Pit (5-6).hazardDisable: @Check[thievery|dc:22] (trained) to disable the trap door mechanism
Thorns of the Rose Pit (5-6).hazardReset: Creatures can still fall into the trap, but the trap door must be reset manually for the trap to become hidden again.
Thorns of the Rose Pit (5-6).name: Thorns of the Rose Pit (5-6)

Tired Dockhand.description:
Working to load and unload cargo from ships, dockhands are considered unruly, but many stay focused and work hard until the job is done.

Society is built upon the backs of laborers.

FmriI9fZfj3I2QS1.description: The dockhand Interacts to either draw a bottle of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.UMAXLDpI6YLSfYX1]{Alcohol} or pick up a nearby unattended bottle of alcohol, then drinks the whole thing. For 1 minute, the dockhand gains a +2 item bonus to melee damage rolls and saving throws against fear but is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard}.
FmriI9fZfj3I2QS1.name: Swig

WFP4NLE0aiemGMh3.description: A mix of flexible and molded boiled leather, a suit of this type of armor provides some protection with maximum flexibility.
WFP4NLE0aiemGMh3.name: Work Clothes (Functions as Leather Armor)

ma0kNlN1eN2YPKXO.description:
Requirements The dockhand is adjacent to a crate

Effect The dockhand picks up a crate and heaves it up to 15 feet. Upon landing, the crate breaks open in a @Template[type:burst|distance:5]. Each creature in the area takes @Damage[1d6[bludgeoning]|options:area-damage] damage with a @Check[reflex|dc:13|basic|options:area-effect] save, and the area is difficult terrain until cleared.
ma0kNlN1eN2YPKXO.name: Heft Crate

z1TGYF24OzHmgdjp.description:
Alcohol is a common substance available in stunning variety. The Price of a dose of alcohol depends on the specific beverage. You can't recover from the sickened condition from alcohol while affected.

If you fail a saving throw against alcohol other than initial saves, the affliction's stage doesn't increase; the only way to increase the stage of alcohol's affliction is to consume more alcohol.

Activate A Interact (Ingested)

Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:12]

Onset 10 minutes

Stage 1 +1 item bonus to saving throws against fear (10 minutes)

Stage 2 @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard}, +1 item bonus to saving throws against fear effects (10 minutes)

Stage 3 @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1}, off-guard, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} (10 minutes)

Stage 4 @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} (10 minutes)

Stage 5 clumsy 2, sickened 2, and stupefied 2 (10 minutes)

Stage 6 @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious} (8 hours)

Stage 7 death
z1TGYF24OzHmgdjp.name: Whiskey

Tired Dockhand.name: Tired Dockhand

Tough Puddles Ghoul.description:
Ghouls stalkers are ravenous undead who haunt graveyards and eat corpses.

Few creatures are more ubiquitous to sinister locations such as lonely graveyards and ruined crypts than the flesh-eating undead known as ghouls.

Ycy1nGPHEsariBcE.description: The Puddles ghoul jumps up to half its Speed or swims up to half its swim Speed. This movement doesn't trigger reactions.
Ycy1nGPHEsariBcE.name: Swift Movement

nwmDJVsxF9KS0Ji9.description:
Requirements A @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious}, or willing creature is within the tough Puddles ghoul's reach

Effect The ghoul bites the creature, slurping its blood. This requires an Athletics check against the target's Fortitude DC if the victim is grabbed and is automatic for any of the other conditions. The victim takes @Damage[(1d8+3)[piercing]] damage and the tough Puddles ghoul regains @Damage[4[healing]] Hit Points, gaining any excess HP as temporary HP.
nwmDJVsxF9KS0Ji9.name: Slurp Blood

Tough Puddles Ghoul.name: Tough Puddles Ghoul

Trained Triceratops.description:
Triceratopses are muscular quadrupeds with powerful short legs, thick necks, and heads crowned by a wide, bony frill. Though they bear three large horns, they use these bony protrusions only to defend themselves or fight for dominance. Short-tempered and obstinate, triceratopses are unlikely to back down from a fight unless they are hopelessly outmatched, and the creatures are known to fight to the death for no apparent reason beyond stubbornness. Triceratopses often serve as mounts for humanoids, particularly giants, who can comfortably ride behind the dinosaurs' protective bone frills. A triceratops is 30 feet long and weighs as much as 10 tons.

Remnants from the world's primeval era, these enormous reptilian animals still exist in large numbers in remote wildernesses or underground in magical Darklands caverns. Lizardfolk, orcs, giants, and other humanoids who live near dinosaurs use the animals as mounts, guards, or hunting beasts. Occasionally, rich nobles will collect dinosaurs to display them in menageries, which almost inevitably leads to cast-offs being nursed back to health by druids and other champions of nature. When dinosaurs establish themselves in regions outside their normal habitats, it's often the result of a large collection being released.

D2tbPVYsNe8XmlsW.description:
Trigger The rider is targeted with an attack.

Requirements A creature must be mounted on the triceratops.

Effect The triceratops intercepts the attack with its bony frill. The rider gains a +2 circumstance bonus to its AC against the triggering attack.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.enrTKgEzu2quCj0z]{Effect: Frill Defense}
D2tbPVYsNe8XmlsW.name: Frill Defense

OW9KKx3Offpslmah.description: The triceratops Strides up to 10 feet and then makes a Strike.
OW9KKx3Offpslmah.name: Lumbering Charge

bWfE1BR1kz8fIanF.description: A triceratops deals 2d6 extra persistent bleed damage to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone} targets it hits with its horns.
bWfE1BR1kz8fIanF.name: Vicious Gore

Trained Triceratops.name: Trained Triceratops

Treacherous Scree.description: The footing on this sloped ground appears to be stable at first glance, but the tiny rocks that cover it are loosely packed and prone to slipping.
Treacherous Scree.name: Treacherous Scree

Turbulent Koi Egg.description: A raging storm covers the mountain lake as spring water levitates from the lake to fall back down in a driving spiral of steaming rain. In the depths of the storm, barely visible, is a tiny koi egg surrounded by three bands of water.
Turbulent Koi Egg.hazardDisable: @Check[arcana|dc:27], @Check[religion|dc:27], @Check[nature|dc:27], or @Check[occultism|dc:27] to purify the magic corrupting the ascension ritual, or @Check[diplomacy|dc:30] or @Check[performance|dc:30] to soothe the spirit within the koi egg and give it the strength to fight off the corruption itself; four total successes are required to purify the ritual, each of the first three successes purifying one ring of water and the final one halting the ritual itself. If the cursed comb has not been removed from the ritual site, then succeeding on this final check merely halts the ritual; if the cursed comb has been removed from the ritual site, then succeeding on this final check completes the ascension ritual.
Turbulent Koi Egg.hazardReset: The turbulent koi egg can attempt to hatch again, restarting the ascension ritual, after 1000 years of Xalreonshin's care.
Turbulent Koi Egg.hazardRoutine: (1 action) Torrential water descends from the sky, taking the shape of a dragon that smashes into one creature within 60 feet of the egg. The dragon always targets the creature that is closest to the egg, dealing @Damage[2d10[bludgeoning],2d10[fire]]{2d10 bludgeoning damage and 2d10 fire} damage in a spray of boiling water (@Check[fortitude|dc:26] save). Creatures that fail the save are pushed 10 feet away. Creatures that have the earth trait, are carrying an item with the earth trait, or are otherwise strongly tied to elemental earth (such as an earth elemental sorcerer or kineticist) get the result one degree of success better than the outcome of their save, as the power of elemental earth overcomes water.
Turbulent Koi Egg.name: Turbulent Koi Egg

Typhoon Koi Egg.description: A raging storm covers the mountain lake as spring water levitates from the lake to fall back down in a driving spiral of steaming rain. In the depths of the storm, barely visible, is a tiny koi egg surrounded by three bands of water.
Typhoon Koi Egg.hazardDisable: @Check[arcana|dc:30], @Check[religion|dc:30], @Check[nature|dc:30], or @Check[occultism|dc:30] to purify the magic corrupting the ascension ritual, or @Check[diplomacy|dc:33] or @Check[performance|dc:33] to soothe the spirit within the koi egg and give it the strength to fight off the corruption itself; four total successes are required to purify the ritual, each of the first three successes purifying one ring of water and the final one halting the ritual itself. If the cursed comb has not been removed from the ritual site, then succeeding on this final check merely halts the ritual; if the cursed comb has been removed from the ritual site, then succeeding on this final check completes the ascension ritual.
Typhoon Koi Egg.hazardReset: The turbulent koi egg can attempt to hatch again, restarting the ascension ritual, after 1000 years of Xalreonshin's care.
Typhoon Koi Egg.hazardRoutine: (1 action) Torrential water descends from the sky, taking the shape of a dragon that smashes into one creature within 60 feet of the egg. The dragon always targets the creature that is closest to the egg, dealing @Damage[(2d12+2)[bludgeoning],2d12[fire]]{2d12+2 bludgeoning damage and 2d12 fire} damage in a spray of boiling water (@Check[fortitude|dc:28] save). Creatures that fail the save are pushed 10 feet away. Creatures that have the earth trait, are carrying an item with the earth trait, or are otherwise strongly tied to elemental earth (such as an earth elemental sorcerer or kineticist) get the result one degree of success better than the outcome of their save, as the power of elemental earth overcomes water.
Typhoon Koi Egg.name: Typhoon Koi Egg

1eVSfQ2hcf3vsAgD.description:
The Ulfen bodyguard attacks the target, pushing them back and away from their charge. The bodyguard makes a Strike against the creature, then attempts to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.7blmbDrQFNfdT731]{Shove} their target. Depending on the outcome of their Strike, there may be additional effects.

Critical Success The Ulfen bodyguard gains a +2 circumstance bonus to their attempt to Shove.

Success The Ulfen bodyguard gains a +1 circumstance bonus to their attempt to Shove.

Failure There is no effect.

Critical Failure The Ulfen bodyguard is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} until the start of their next turn.
1eVSfQ2hcf3vsAgD.name: Back Away!

Fmkei93T69EHT8Zp.description:
Trigger A creature within 30 feet deals damage to Matriarch Szvetneera

Effect The Ulfen bodyguard lets out a threating bellow at whoever injured their ward. They then attempt a check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.2u915NdUyQan6uKF]{Demoralize} against the triggering creature, gaining a +2 circumstance bonus to the check.
Fmkei93T69EHT8Zp.name: Face Me!

Umberweed.description:
The mischievous dragon sprites called draxies have dueled their pixie cousins for the title of ultimate prankster for centuries. They exercise patience and planning to create the perfect pranks, spending months, or even years, on their efforts. One exception to their flighty nature is the elucrea, a lifelong bond between a draxie and a creature they're particularly fond of, typically one with a good sense of humor. According to draxie legend, a little piece of a draxie's spirit remembers being united as the ancient fey dragonet Elucredassa, and that causes draxies to yearn for such connections with others.

Elusive, flighty, and ebullient, sprites are what many villagers first imagine when they hear the terms "fey" or "fairy." While their dispositions vary, all sprites share a connection to magic and a diminutive size. This family of fey shares its name with its slightest and most populous member, the common sprite.

5eqtzIqWpDscyCIh.description:
The draxie breathes magical dust in a @Template[cone|distance:15]. Roll [[/r 1d4]] to determine the effect. Each creature in the area must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:15] save or be affected.

The draxie can't use Draxie Dust again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Draxie Dust]]{1d4 rounds}.

  1. The target takes the effects of the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.vLA0q0WOK2YPuJs6]{Charm} spell.
  2. The target loses its last 5 minutes of memory.
  3. The target takes the effects of a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.o4lRVTwSxnOOn5vl]{Sleep} spell.
  4. For 1 minute, the target is in a state of euphoria that makes it @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1}.
5eqtzIqWpDscyCIh.name: Draxie Dust

Umberweed.name: Umberweed

Unstable Furniture Archway.description: This unsteady pile of furniture is piled to the top of this usually high-ceilinged room. There looks to be some space to squeeze through to the other side, but even the slightest touch causes the stack to destabilize, and there's so much that once it begins to fall, it's difficult to stop.
Unstable Furniture Archway.hazardDisable: @Check[athletics|dc:21] to knock the pile over in a safe direction or @Check[thievery|dc:19] (trained) to carefully rearrange the furniture to a stable configuration.
Unstable Furniture Archway.hazardRoutine: On its initiative, the pile expands into an adjacent space, dealing creatures in that space @Damage[(1d6+4)[bludgeoning]] damage with a @Check[reflex|dc:18|basic] save, pushing any creatures in that space into an adjacent empty space, and making that space impassable until cleared. If no adjacent empty space is available, the pile buries the creature, suffocating it. Clearing a space or pulling a creature out requires a @Check[athletics|dc:15] check.
Unstable Furniture Archway.name: Unstable Furniture Archway

Very Haunted Hollows.description: The spirits of innumerable dryads and peaceful wood elementals, ripped from their bodies as they were turned into furniture, writhe and seethe, lashing out at both living and undead alike.
Very Haunted Hollows.hazardDisable:
@Check[diplomacy|dc:20] (trained), @Check[nature|dc:20] (trained), or @Check[religion|dc:20] (trained) to set the spirits to rest or @Check[deception|dc:23], @Check[intimidation|dc:23], or @Check[occultism|dc:23] to convince the spirits that their eternal rest is coming soon.

A PC may make a Strike against AC 19 to destroy a single table or chair in the room, this functions as a successful check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.HCl3pzVefiv9ZKQW]{Aid} another PC attempting to disable the haunt; two total successes are required to disable the haunt. If all of the tables and chairs are destroyed, the haunt is temporarily disabled until dawn of the next day.
Very Haunted Hollows.hazardRoutine: (two actions) The Haunted Hollows haunt uses one table flip Strike or two chair toss Strikes at random creatures in the area, favoring those who are trying to disable the haunt first. The table flip Strikes originate with any table in the room, destroying the table in the process. The chair toss Strikes originate with any chair or bar stool in the room, destroying that object in the process. If the haunt is not disabled, these objects reform and return to their original positions at dawn of the next day.
Very Haunted Hollows.name: Very Haunted Hollows

8KPW4LTQP7yrPNJY.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:19]

Stage 2 @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} (1d3 days)

Veteran Bodyguard.description:
Hired to protect someone famous or powerful, bodyguards use intimidation, quick wits, and martial skill to keep their charges safe. Such mercenaries might be auxiliaries to a noble's personal guards, but with special directives to safeguard their patrons.

Whether they're hired to wage war, protect a caravan, or infiltrate an impenetrable fortress, there's ample work for mercenaries all over Golarion.

1MkRQqE6U0WNXi2D.description:
Trigger A creature attacks the subject of bodyguard's defense

Effect The bodyguard makes a Strike against the triggering creature.
1MkRQqE6U0WNXi2D.name: Bodyguard's Reprisal

LtLpVRWe7Qsb7Y8A.description:
The bodyguard grants an adjacent ally a +2 circumstance bonus to AC. This lasts until the start of the bodyguard's next turn or until the ally is no longer adjacent, whichever comes first.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.IfUod2VxNmZMGGPq]{Effect: Bodyguard's Defense}
LtLpVRWe7Qsb7Y8A.name: Bodyguard's Defense

Veteran Bodyguard.name: Veteran Bodyguard

17N9SiA9mG2WfitQ.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect The Pure Legionnaire Strides twice. If they end their movement within melee reach of at least one enemy, they can make a melee Strike against that enemy.
17N9SiA9mG2WfitQ.name: Sudden Charge

TLaTqD2bEjWTGD7s.name: +2 Status to All Saves Against Divine Magic

YyOkIdP52leMxTUP.description: The scimitars of the Pure Legion have been enchanted specifically to take down divine spellcasters. Melee Strikes against clerics, champions, and other creatures capable of casting divine spells do an additional 2d6 mental damage.
YyOkIdP52leMxTUP.name: Smite Divine

nknQxhl4L8wHTo3B.description: When the Pure Legionnaire rolls a success on a save against an effect or spell from the divine tradition, they get a critical success instead.
nknQxhl4L8wHTo3B.name: May No Mortal Be Beholden

Veteran Pure Legionnaire.name: Veteran Pure Legionnaire
Veteran Pure Legionnaire.npcAllSaves: +2 on all saves against divine magic

Void Font.description: The font is hidden just under the water's surface. It spews foul brown sludge into the pristine waters, leaving them reeking and polluted as they move downstream. It can be reached without swimming, but not without getting wet.
Void Font.hazardDisable: @Check[nature|dc:20] (trained) to draw upon the suppressed Primal energies of this place to cleanse the font, @Check[religion|dc:26] (expert) to suppress the void energies, @Check[thievery|dc:23] to undo the magic sigils allowing the font to operate; two total successes are required to disable the font.
Void Font.hazardReset: The void font deactivates 1 minute after all creatures leave the area but resets immediately thereafter.
Void Font.hazardRoutine: The void font uses its actions each turn to spew a single void geyser.
Void Font.name: Void Font

Weak Air Scamp.description:
A pale blue head and paper-thin wings peek out from the cloud that clings to the air scamp. Air scamps are short-sighted and flighty, even relative to their kin; they are as likely to fly recklessly into battle as they are to whine in terror at a loud noise.

Elemental scamps are bat-like critters marked by elemental powers. Scamps are dispatched from the Elemental Planes by more powerful residents or called to the Universe by neophyte summoners. All scamps have a hint of magical power due to a lingering connection to their home plane, which they largely use to pull simple pranks.

Scamps rapidly form a pecking order of cleverness. Humanoids often confuse scamps when meeting such creatures for the first time. These confused scamps usually resort to an escalating series of pranks and mischief, seeing what they can get away with to establish their place in the hierarchy.

1CENtBTrhih9EKVU.description: The air scamp ignores the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} condition from fog and mist.
1CENtBTrhih9EKVU.name: Fog Vision

yC1vWH3Q9V6GoICd.description:
The air scamp creates cutting winds in a @Template[cone|distance:15] that deal @Damage[(2d6-4)[slashing]|options:area-damage] damage to each creature within the area (@Check[reflex|dc:15|basic|options:area-effect] save). A creature that fails its save is also pushed back 10 feet.

The air scamp can't use Sirocco Breath again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Sirocco Breath]]{1d4 rounds}.
yC1vWH3Q9V6GoICd.name: Sirocco Breath

Weak Air Scamp.name: Weak Air Scamp

Weak Animated Flame.description:
Although arguably quite friendly, fire scamps are considered far more dangerous than their kin. They delight in fire and playing pranks on everyone they befriend. Even given time to understand others' dislike of fire, most fire scamps enjoy the feel of flames enough to constantly test their limits.

Compared to the nations of other scamps, the nations on the Plane of Fire are by far the strongest. This backing inspires fire scamps to challenge authority more quickly than the others.

Elemental scamps are bat-like critters marked by elemental powers. Scamps are dispatched from the Elemental Planes by more powerful residents or called to the Universe by neophyte summoners. All scamps have a hint of magical power due to a lingering connection to their home plane, which they largely use to pull simple pranks.

Scamps rapidly form a pecking order of cleverness. Humanoids often confuse scamps when meeting such creatures for the first time. These confused scamps usually resort to an escalating series of pranks and mischief, seeing what they can get away with to establish their place in the hierarchy.

JPfXLDy2dYseqUop.description: The animated flame ignores the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} condition from smoke.
JPfXLDy2dYseqUop.name: Smoke Vision

UnZj5Xyb8m8zt4Wk.description: If the animated flame leaves the village, willingly or otherwise, it becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} for 2 rounds.
UnZj5Xyb8m8zt4Wk.name: Panic of Failure Foreseen

gMRZ46sjaLERrmao.description:
The animated flame breathes flames in a @Template[cone|distance:15] that deals @Damage[(2d4-4)[fire]|options:area-damage] damage to each creature within the area (@Check[reflex|dc:15|basic|options:area-effect] save). Creatures that fail the save also take @Damage[1d4[persistent,fire]] damage.

The animated flame can't use Flame Breath again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Flame Breath]]{1d4 rounds}.
gMRZ46sjaLERrmao.name: Flame Breath

yAvraJf1ksBAcCOl.description: If the animated flame starts its turn outside the village after it arrives, it dissipates.
yAvraJf1ksBAcCOl.name: Price of Failure

Weak Animated Flame.name: Weak Animated Flame

Weak Bottlenose Dolphin.description:
The bottlenose dolphin is the most common and widespread species of dolphin. They are social predators who hunt shallow seas and rivers in large family groups called pods. Sailors are fond of bottlenose dolphins and frequently tell of how they've saved drowning mariners or protected crew from sharks with blows from their powerful snouts.

Dolphins encompass a wide range of aquatic mammals, all of which are social, intelligent, and widespread throughout the world's oceans.

TBp1tYUPtYoOEonO.description: A bottlenose dolphin can use its hearing as a precise sense at the listed range, but only underwater.
TBp1tYUPtYoOEonO.name: Aquatic Echolocation 120 feet

jN9qLXiQfaOBlFfC.description:
The bottlenose dolphin @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.c8TGiZ48ygoSPofx]{Swims} twice and then makes a snout Strike. As long as it moved at least 20 feet, it gains a +1 circumstance bonus to its attack roll.

A Large or smaller creature hit by this attack must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:14] save or be @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for 1 round.
jN9qLXiQfaOBlFfC.name: Ramming Speed

khgGPSxgTQcgev3o.description: A bottlenose dolphin can hold its breath for 2 hours.
khgGPSxgTQcgev3o.name: Deep Breath

Weak Bottlenose Dolphin.name: Weak Bottlenose Dolphin

2AazzXyHKMk4CBqa.description: The disciple raises their heavy crimson cloak, providing them with a +1 circumstance bonus to their AC and also giving them access to the Snagging Catch reaction.
2AazzXyHKMk4CBqa.name: Cloak and Dagger

BuPJNWPun4flCMBD.description:
Requirements The disciple has their crimson cloak raised

Trigger The disciple is attacked by a melee weapon

Effect After the attack's result is resolved, the disciple attempts to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.Dt6B1slsBy8ipJu9]{Disarm} the triggering weapon, gaining a +1 circumstance bonus. The cloak is destroyed after this action.
BuPJNWPun4flCMBD.name: Snagging Catch

kT4mJsqHWAdlpSzN.description: The disciple's strikes deal 2d6 extra damage to creatures within reach of at least one of the disciple's allies.
kT4mJsqHWAdlpSzN.name: Pattern Attack

Weak Ghoul Soldier (PFS 6-99).description:
Retaining their martial skill, these powerful ghouls are not afraid to meet their foe in the open, feeding on the flesh of their fallen opponents to learn their combat abilities.

Few creatures are more ubiquitous to sinister locations such as lonely graveyards and ruined crypts than the flesh-eating undead known as ghouls.

KHysHMKYybPFeqI5.description:
Requirements A @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious} creature is within the ghoul's reach

Effect The ghoul whispers dark thoughts and vile cravings into the creature's ears. The creature must save against the forbidden cravings curse.

Forbidden Cravings (curse) A creature can still eat and drink while sickened by this curse

Saving Throw @Check[will|dc:16|traits:curse]

Stage 1 carrier with no ill effects (1 day)

Stage 2 @Damage[2d6[void]] damage and the target is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} until it consumes raw meat (1 day)

Stage 3 as stage 2

Stage 4 as stage 2 unless the target has consumed raw meat in the past 24 hours, then it takes @Damage[4d6[void]] damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} until it consumes raw meat;

Stage 5 if the creature has eaten raw meat in the past 24 hours, it dies and rises as a ghoul, if not, it returns to stage 4
KHysHMKYybPFeqI5.name: Ghoul Whispers

R9q9hezMY3S2b5ha.description: The ghoul jumps up to half its Speed. This movement doesn't trigger reactions.
R9q9hezMY3S2b5ha.name: Swift Leap

Z7PO71C8UMa9vrP4.description:
Requirements The ghoul is adjacent to the corpse of a creature that died within the last hour.

Effect The ghoul devours a chunk of the corpse and regains @Damage[2d6[healing]] Hit Points.

It can regain Hit Points from any given corpse only once.
Z7PO71C8UMa9vrP4.name: Consume Flesh

dbJMknRXkshhKBXb.description:
[[/r 1d20+8]]{+8} skill modifier

Frequency once per hour

Effect The ghoul calls upon knowledge it retains from one creature it has consumed in the past 7 days. The ghoul attempts a skill check using a skill in which the consumed creature was trained (if it's unclear whether the creature was trained, the GM decides). The ghoul is treated as trained and uses the high skill modifier for the ghoul's level. This takes the same amount of actions or time as usual for the check.

The ghoul can instead automatically learn something specific known by a creature it consumed in the last 7 days, like the location of a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Hidden} treasure or the name of a loved one. The ghoul can do this only once for a given creature, no matter how much of its flesh the ghoul consumed.
dbJMknRXkshhKBXb.name: Grave Knowledge

Weak Ghoul Soldier (PFS 6-99).name: Weak Ghoul Soldier (PFS 6-99)

Ghouls stalkers are ravenous undead who haunt graveyards and eat corpses.

Few creatures are more ubiquitous to sinister locations such as lonely graveyards and ruined crypts than the flesh-eating undead known as ghouls.

It can regain Hit Points from any given corpse only once.
7RTjFlVzsxhjtwX4.name: Consume Flesh

The ghoul is treated as trained and uses the high skill modifier for the ghoul's level. This takes the same amount of actions or time as usual for the check.

The ghoul can instead automatically learn something specific known by a creature it consumed in the last 7 days, like the location of a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Hidden} treasure or the name of a loved one. The ghoul can do this only once for a given creature, no matter how much of its flesh the ghoul consumed.

Stage 4 as stage 2 unless the target has consumed raw meat in the past 24 hours, then it takes @Damage[4d6[void]] damage and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} until it consumes raw meat;

Stage 5 if the creature has eaten raw meat in the past 24 hours, it dies and rises as a ghoul, if not, it returns to stage 4

Weak Gluttonous Geode.description:
The vast ranks of earth elementals have been slow to respond to the return of the elemental lords and the Planes of Metal and Wood. These events have not broken the mountains, nor have they blown away the sands.

Earthy Emotions

Earth elementals talk even less than most elementals. They're ponderous, weighing decisions so slowly they can crush the energy from a discussion. Their foremost concern is whether a situation can be endured. Though a rare or resplendent treasure might entice an earth elemental, it's difficult to spur any sense of urgency in them without the presence of an immediate threat.

JQEFb9KA6XUO7dyb.description:
Requirements The geode is attached to a creature

Effect The geode deals @Damage[1d4[bludgeoning]] damage to the creature it's attached to (@Check[fortitude|dc:15|basic] save).
JQEFb9KA6XUO7dyb.name: Gnaw

iiNeC7jyAcDS6aGh.description: The geode Leaps up to 15 feet and makes a crystal teeth Strike. If it hits a creature larger than itself, it can attach to that creature. Doing so is like Grabbing the creature (@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escape} DC 15), but the geode moves with that creature rather than holding it in place. The geode is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} while attached. If the geode is killed or pushed away while attached to a creature, that creature takes @Damage[1[bleed]]{1 persistent bleed} damage. Escaping the attached geode or removing the geode in other ways doesn't cause bleed damage.
iiNeC7jyAcDS6aGh.name: Attach

Weak Gluttonous Geode.name: Weak Gluttonous Geode

Weak Mummy Guardian (PFS 6-99).description:
The majority of mummy guardians were created by cruel and selfish masters to serve as guardians to protect their tombs from intruders. The traditional method of creating a mummy guardian is a laborious and sadistic process that begins well before the poor soul to be transformed is dead. The victim is ritualistically starved of nourishing food and instead fed strange spices, preservative agents, and toxins intended to quicken the desiccation of the flesh. The victim remains immobile but painfully aware during the final stages, as its now-useless entrails are extracted. The victim is then shrouded in funerary wrappings and entombed within a necromantically ensorcelled sarcophagus to await instructions in the potentially distant future. While it's certainly possible to use other methods to create a mummy guardian from an already-deceased body, those who seek to create these foul undead as their guardians in the afterlife often feel that such methods result in inferior undead—the pain and agony of death by mummification being an essential step in the process.

Regardless of the method of their creation, mummy guardians are more than just physical shells of flesh and bone. They retain fragmented, distorted versions of their minds, with only enough memories of their living personality remaining to fuel their undead anger and jealousy of those who yet live. This burning rage only intensifies over the centuries of waiting within a crypt for the chance to actually act, and thus, when most mummy guardians are awoken by tomb robbers or adventurers, they stop at nothing in pursuit of spiteful slaughter.

While many cultures practice mummification for benign reasons, undead mummies are created through grueling rituals, typically to provide eternally vigilant guardians. Much more rarely, a body mummified without those special rites can rise again due to its hatred of the living.

F11GjKJxm8bHuaf6.description:
Trigger A creature within 30 feet eats or drinks (including an alchemical item or potion)

Effect The food or drink burns like the caustic substances fed to the mummy before its death. If the creature fails a @Check[fortitude|dc:22|options:inflicts:sickened] save, they become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} after they finish the consumption and can't reduce their sickened condition while within 30 feet of any mummy.
F11GjKJxm8bHuaf6.name: Blighted Consumption

PwrDf49KhBAgWAGl.description: The guardian's weakness to alchemical items not only applies to damage from alchemical items, but the guardian also takes 5 damage when splashed with non-damaging alchemical items or dosed with alchemical poisons, even if they're immune to their other effects.
PwrDf49KhBAgWAGl.name: Alchemical Weakness

uvteCuJBp9CEBvPJ.description:
Requirements The mummy's last action was a successful fist Strike

Effect The mummy shares the pain of its dying moments with the target of that Strike. That creature takes @Damage[3d8[void]] damage with a @Check[will|dc:22|basic] save. If the creature critically fails the saving throw, it can't speak for 1 round, including to Cast a Spell.
uvteCuJBp9CEBvPJ.name: Choking Pain

Weak Mummy Guardian (PFS 6-99).name: Weak Mummy Guardian (PFS 6-99)

Weak Water Wisp.description:
Water wisps are swimming spheres of foam and water, perpetually humming with a wash of soft sounds. They're gentle, nurturing, and quick to help anyone in need.

Wisps are tiny elemental beings that emerged during the creation of the Elemental Planes. The first wisps roamed the Inner Sphere in shifting symphonies that traded members with their every meeting. These symphonies of free wisps created music out of their combined resonances, but when the evil Elemental Lords realized the value of the wisps' resonance, they captured whole symphonies for use as servants.

Wisps attune to each other and to those they surround themselves with. This attunement makes them naturally supportive allies. Free wisps still roam the Inner Sphere and the Material Plane, but they're usually shy and hide themselves from strangers. However, they happily offer their service to those who show them kindness. They especially find themselves drawn to spellcasters who practice elemental magic; these wisps usually watch from afar but sometimes approach those who seem safe to become familiars or comrades.

Free wisps who find one another become close almost immediately. They get especially excited when they find wisps of elements other than their own, showing none of the animosity some elementals exhibit toward other types. Instead, they join in an excited dance, emitting resonances that faintly echo the symphonies of ancient days.

0fDCOqKLdjm45yXu.description:
30 feet. All wisps vibrate at a frequency attuned to their element, resonating with and empowering all creatures and effects sharing that trait.

A creature in the area gains a +1 status bonus to attack and damage rolls for effects with the water trait; a creature with the elemental and water traits gains this bonus to all attack and damage rolls.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.1dwMVgBHfT4qO4OS]{Effect: Resonance}
0fDCOqKLdjm45yXu.name: Resonance

0fGH8UJJm4ccTubw.description:
Trigger An ally within 30 feet that benefited from the wisp's resonance in the last hour is targeted by an attack

Effect The wisp detonates itself in a small elemental explosion that gives temporary Hit Points equal to half the wisp's current Hit Points to allies within @Template[emanation|distance:30]{30 feet} that have benefited from the wisp's resonance in the last hour. These temporary Hit Points last 1 hour.

A wisp that uses this reaction is permanently destroyed, and it can be restored only by a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.6dDtGIUerazSHIOu]{Wish} spell or similarly powerful effect. If an ability would prevent the wisp's destruction (for instance, if the wisp is summoned and would merely be dismissed), Accord Essence has no effect.
0fGH8UJJm4ccTubw.name: Accord Essence

43AUXc5WoGyh1pKT.description:
The wisp puts out all fires in a single 5-foot square.

It extinguishes non-magical fire of that size or smaller automatically and attempts to counteract magical fires (counteract modifier [[/r 1d20+6 #Counteract]]{+6}).
43AUXc5WoGyh1pKT.name: Drench

BgiZcqILhEbxEVG7.description: When a water wisp rolls a critical failure on a check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.HCl3pzVefiv9ZKQW]{Aid}, they get a failure instead, and when they roll a success, they get a critical success instead.
BgiZcqILhEbxEVG7.name: In Concert

aw8UyWcvmu5VncsT.description: The water wisp ignores the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} condition from mist and fog.
aw8UyWcvmu5VncsT.name: Mist Vision

Weak Water Wisp.name: Weak Water Wisp

ucptM7OaFP5CpesA.description:
Frequency once per minute

Effect The wood beetle swings its body around, targeting up to two adjacent creatures and dealing @Damage[1d4[bludgeoning]] damage with a @Check[reflex|dc:14|basic] save.
ucptM7OaFP5CpesA.name: Body Bash

Weak Wood Scamp.description:
These moss colonies coalesce over a century into the rough facsimile of a large sloth, right down to mimicking the unique structure of the animal's fur that attracts additional fungi and pollinating insects. Unless summoned or attacked, they rarely leave the trees upon which they first formed.

At first glance, wood elementals might not seem to have the same destructive potential as their cousins from the Planes of Fire, Water, or Air, but don't be fooled. The woods can be a dangerous place.

Though some resemble animals, the elemental beasts presented here are still plants, and their life cycles reflect it. Vegetable lambs grow on rooted stalks, from which they can't be removed until they've matured (or perhaps ripened), leaving them dependent on their immediate surroundings for food. Moss sloths are little more than lumps of green fluff for the first century of their existence, only gaining limited mobility once they can grow their defensive wooden claws.

Wild But Unwild

Many wood elementals are created by kizidhars and other powerful creatures on the Plane of Wood and placed in rote roles. Populating nature preserves and sprawling estates, they can be unsure how to behave if released into the wild. They're essentially born domesticated and will likely act far differently than the wild creatures they mimic, even in natural environments. Their natural predators are few, putting the elementals at less risk, although they're still sometimes eaten by giant termites or captured by some as pets.

A Brain By Any Other Name

Even if Lady Shumunue taught the wood elementals' ancestors to mimic animals, a wood elemental's consciousness is contained not in a brain but in its root system. Entities like nursery crawlers, living groves, and carved beasts use this to their advantage. That an elemental's wooden body can be carved and crafted, apparently without lasting harm, implies that they might not feel pain so long as their roots remain undamaged.

OkAkqlgDi1isALeF.description: The wood scamp breathes choking pollen in a @Template[cone|distance:15] that deals @Damage[(2d6-4)[poison]|options:area-damage] damage to each creature within the area (@Check[reflex|dc:15|basic|options:area-effect] save; creatures who don't need to breathe are immune). The wood scamp can't Breathe Pollen again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Breathe Pollen]]{1d4 rounds}.
OkAkqlgDi1isALeF.name: Breathe Pollen

cDhKXGyP6SctggAU.description: The wood scamp breaks off one of its thorn-like claws in the target's skin, dealing 1 persistent bleed damage until the thorn is removed, which requires an Interact action. This damage is cumulative with each thorn caught in a creature's skin.
cDhKXGyP6SctggAU.name: Thorn Puncture

Weak Wood Scamp.name: Weak Wood Scamp

Weak Wood Wisp.description:
Like other wisps, wood wisps roam their plane and attune to other wisps, wandering with them in symphonies. Because of their willingness to bond, wood wisps appear outside their home plane more than other wood elementals, though they're still relatively rare compared to other wisps.

Wood wisps resemble coconuts trailed by thick nests of branches that cover and conceal even deeper webs of thorny vines. They are, unfortunately, both unaware of the pain these thorns can cause fleshy creatures and very physically affectionate in their eagerness to offer assistance.

9gAaXXK7fWFvAfU8.description:
Trigger An ally within 30 feet that benefited from the wisp's resonance in the last hour is targeted by an attack

Effect The wisp detonates itself in a small elemental explosion of leaves and pollen. This gives temporary Hit Points equal to half the wisp's current HP to all allies within 30 feet that have benefited from the wisp's resonance aura in the past hour. These temporary Hit Points last 1 hour.

A wisp that uses this reaction is permanently destroyed and can be restored only by a @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.6dDtGIUerazSHIOu]{Wish} ritual or similarly powerful effect. If an ability would prevent the wisp's destruction (for instance, if the wisp is summoned and would merely be dismissed), Accord Essence has no effect.
9gAaXXK7fWFvAfU8.name: Accord Essence

Y9gukafwaFEAEqG0.description:
30 feet.

All wisps vibrate at a frequency attuned to their element, resonating with and empowering all creatures and effects sharing that trait. A creature in the area gains a +1 status bonus to attack and damage rolls for effects with the plant or wood trait; a creature with the elemental trait and either plant trait or wood trait gains this bonus to all attack and damage rolls. For wood wisps, this bonus also applies to nonmagical wooden weapons, such as staves and clubs.
Y9gukafwaFEAEqG0.name: Resonance

cM7y0IGI7NQFI9f3.description: When a wood wisp rolls a critical failure on a check to Aid, they get a failure instead, and when they roll a success, they get a critical success instead.
cM7y0IGI7NQFI9f3.name: In Concert

Weak Wood Wisp.name: Weak Wood Wisp

Weak Xurgimoth.description:
The magic that flows through primal dragons can manifest more animalistic or bestial features in a given type of dragon. Notably among these are the massive paired horns of the horned dragon. While their bulky frames, natural coloration, and prominent ridged scales are all remarkable in their own way, it's the horns that are most obvious and striking at first glance. Horned dragons use their horns to impale their prey in a quick and brutal display of their might. They are generally contemplative and have a fixation on knowledge and self-discipline, traits belied by their bestial appearance. As a result, horned dragons are generally more open to speaking with outsiders.

Dragons come in myriad forms, with many having magical abilities or connections to magic. Some dragons draw greater power from magic than others, allowing them to manifest abilities or alter their physiques with prolonged exposure to magic. These dragons become more powerful as they age and strengthen their connections with their magical origins. Scholars debate the classification of these dragons, with some preferring the name magical dragons and others using traditional dragons due to their connection to specific magical traditions. Regardless of their names, these dragons share a number of characteristics: their ability to tap into magical energies, intensified might and cunning as they grow older, and an inclination to hoard vast amounts of treasure and wealth.

1FbPUVt1mVdHjwrB.description: The horned dragon ignores any difficult terrain caused by plants, such as bushes, vines, and undergrowth. Even plants manipulated by magic don't impede their progress.
1FbPUVt1mVdHjwrB.name: Forest Passage

3Fn7wuVzeuI4kT5H.description:
Requirements The dragon doesn't have a creature impaled on their horn

Effect The dragon attempts to gore a foe. They Stride, then attempt a horn Strike. On a hit, the target becomes impaled on the dragon's horn. The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} while on the horn (and can attempt to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escape} as normal). The dragon doesn't need to use additional actions to keep the impaled creature grabbed. If the dragon moves, they bring the grabbed creature along with them.
3Fn7wuVzeuI4kT5H.name: Impaling Charge

ItyDWQiPz0eJ2hOb.description:
Trigger A creature within reach of the dragon's tail uses a move action or leaves a square during a move action it's using

Effect The dragon makes a tail Strike at the creature with a –2 penalty. If the Strike hits, the dragon disrupts the creature's action.
ItyDWQiPz0eJ2hOb.name: Twisting Tail

Iv8LMCTGw5NLD5aD.description: The dragon makes two claw Strikes and one horn Strike in any order.
Iv8LMCTGw5NLD5aD.name: Draconic Frenzy

VPryni3E3RGw5MdV.description:
The dragon breathes a toxic cloud that deals @Damage[(9d6-4)[poison]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[cone|distance:40] (@Check[fortitude|dc:23|basic|options:area-effect] save).

Whippoorwill Con Rit.description:
The con rit is a hulking aquatic centipede that has traded its hundreds of legs for just as many fins. This sea insect swims with a grace that is just as majestic as it is unnerving. The con rit is dark brown on its dorsal side and sickly yellow on its ventral surface. This makes it much more difficult to spot, whether looking from above or below. Its exoskeleton is as hard as iron, and the shifting of its plates makes an elongated, eerie ringing sound as it swims.

Many once thought the con rit to be a dragon of some kind. This was due not only to its massive size but also to its ability to launch its venom in a concentrated blast. It would use this technique to shoot birds out of the sky or knock sailors off ships. Their movement through the water is also not entirely dissimilar to that of dragons. Those who seek out a con rit's lair in search of treasure are usually disappointed (when they aren't eaten alive by the huge insect).

There are legends that a con rit, much like a phoenix, is reborn after its death. This, however, is not the case. A con rit will make a nest far below the surface of its territory, usually in underwater caves. Throughout its life, a con rit will lay thousands of eggs in its cave that will never hatch. The con rit will eat any egg that gets too old, but there are always large numbers of them remaining. When a con rit dies, it releases a strong-smelling chemical into the air and water that triggers the hatching process. The eggs will slowly crack open within the month, and hundreds of baby con rits will begin to fight each other for territory. By year's end, one will win and reach full maturity. This cycle is what has led to the legends of endless rebirth. Other stories say that every generation of the con rit is ever so slightly smaller, leading to tales of ancient con rits that were hundreds of feet long. However, the size of such legendary insects has yet to be confirmed by scholars who study such things.

1AR7cN1zlEwxiuGD.description: The con rit Swims. During this movement, it can pass through spaces as narrow as 5 feet without Squeezing.
1AR7cN1zlEwxiuGD.name: Undulate

Whippoorwill Electric Eel.description:
Usually found in freshwater rivers and lakes, an electric eel is not particularly aggressive, but its ability to stun predators and prey alike can be dangerous to larger creatures searching for their next meal. Electric eels are more closely related to catfish than to other eels.

Although these long, narrow fish share similarities in appearance, eels are a diverse group of creatures.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1}.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 2}.

Whippoorwill Giant Moray Eel.description:
Giant moray eels dwell in warm, tropical waters and build lairs in narrow, twisting caves made of coral. Their size, speed, and powerful bite make them dangerous to divers and fishers. Giant moray eels have rubbery hides that secrete a layer of mucus, making them difficult to harm with some weapons.

Although these long, narrow fish share similarities in appearance, eels are a diverse group of creatures.

Ghouls stalkers are ravenous undead who haunt graveyards and eat corpses.

Few creatures are more ubiquitous to sinister locations such as lonely graveyards and ruined crypts than the flesh-eating undead known as ghouls.

It can regain Hit Points from any given corpse only once.

Whippoorwill Piranha Swarm.description:
More teeth and fury than body, few fish command as much fear and anxiety as the piranha. They move almost exclusively in schools, overwhelming larger creatures with sheer numbers and ferocity. Piranhas aggress toward sudden disturbances in the water and can smell blood from far away. Harvested piranha teeth serve as excellent cutting tools.

Swimming in vast shoals through open ocean underneath the sparkling sun, lurking deep in the muddy beds of rivers, or schooling in pristine lakes, fish are found nearly anywhere there is water.

E4Nclckgv1bSz78W.description: The piranha swarm can smell blood in the water from up to 1 mile away.
E4Nclckgv1bSz78W.name: Blood Scent

A creature that fails the save also takes @Damage[1d6[bleed]] and takes a -2 circumstance penalty to their Reflex saves against Feeding Frenzy while this damage continues, as the piranhas' frenzy increases in intensity when they smell blood.
uubvbSioie58su3V.name: Feeding Frenzy

Whippoorwill Piranha Swarm.name: Whippoorwill Piranha Swarm

Wood Scamp (Quest 22).description:
These moss colonies coalesce over a century into the rough facsimile of a large sloth, right down to mimicking the unique structure of the animal's fur that attracts additional fungi and pollinating insects. Unless summoned or attacked, they rarely leave the trees upon which they first formed.

At first glance, wood elementals might not seem to have the same destructive potential as their cousins from the Planes of Fire, Water, or Air, but don't be fooled. The woods can be a dangerous place.

Though some resemble animals, the elemental beasts presented here are still plants, and their life cycles reflect it. Vegetable lambs grow on rooted stalks, from which they can't be removed until they've matured (or perhaps ripened), leaving them dependent on their immediate surroundings for food. Moss sloths are little more than lumps of green fluff for the first century of their existence, only gaining limited mobility once they can grow their defensive wooden claws.

Wild But Unwild

Many wood elementals are created by kizidhars and other powerful creatures on the Plane of Wood and placed in rote roles. Populating nature preserves and sprawling estates, they can be unsure how to behave if released into the wild. They're essentially born domesticated and will likely act far differently than the wild creatures they mimic, even in natural environments. Their natural predators are few, putting the elementals at less risk, although they're still sometimes eaten by giant termites or captured by some as pets.

A Brain By Any Other Name

Even if Lady Shumunue taught the wood elementals' ancestors to mimic animals, a wood elemental's consciousness is contained not in a brain but in its root system. Entities like nursery crawlers, living groves, and carved beasts use this to their advantage. That an elemental's wooden body can be carved and crafted, apparently without lasting harm, implies that they might not feel pain so long as their roots remain undamaged.

OkAkqlgDi1isALeF.description: The wood scamp breathes choking pollen in a @Template[cone|distance:15] that deals @Damage[2d6[poison]|options:area-damage] damage to each creature within the area (@Check[reflex|dc:17|basic|options:area-effect] save; creatures who don't need to breathe are immune). The wood scamp can't Breathe Pollen again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Breathe Pollen]]{1d4 rounds}.

If he successfully hits, he deals an additional 2d6 damage (4d6 on a critical hit) on top of the damage from ignition and the greataxe. This counts as two attacks for the purposes of multiple attack penalty, but the penalty does not apply until after Yollen completes this ability. Yollen cannot use Hellish Spellstrike again until he has recharge it using a single action with the concentrate trait or cast his conflux spell.

Young Giant Viper.description:
The giant viper's fangs are a frightening sight, with injection tubes as long as daggers. The sheer amount of venom injected by a giant viper can cause severe blood clotting and leave a victim utterly drained of vitality.

Snakes come in an array of forms, from jungle-dwelling constrictors that wrap around their prey to venomous vipers with deadly bites. Regardless, all snakes consume their prey whole by unhinging their jaws and using powerful muscles to move the food down their throats and into their stomachs.

1fzwu2J1jldVzBPc.description: The giant viper uses an action to coil itself. While Coiled, the reach of its fangs is 10 feet and it has the Reactive Strike reaction. After the giant viper Strikes with its fangs, it becomes uncoiled.
1fzwu2J1jldVzBPc.name: Coil

Young Warg.description:
Wargs hunt in packs like wolves, but their penchant for taunting victims makes them easy to distinguish from their cousins. Orcs and hobgoblins frequently recruit wargs. Most wargs are amenable to this arrangement, but if food should run out, wargs are more than willing to integrate goblinoid flesh into their diet.

The warg is an intelligent and malevolent wolf that dwells among goblins, hobgoblins, orcs, and violent humanoids.

Plague zombies are infested with horrible contagions.

A zombie's only desire is to consume the living. Unthinking and ever-shambling harbingers of death, zombies stop only when they're destroyed.

This shuffling mass of decaying flesh moves with dull but singular focus.

Necromancers most often create these mindless undead as obedient, expendable servitors. Left to its own devices, a zombie seeks only to consume the living, stopping only when its rotting body can no longer hold together.
